sources.full: The World of Light: Player's Guide

deity.name: Erestem
deity.title: God of Light, Life, Compassion and Order

entries: At first, there was nothing. Then, a conscience. Thoughts. Essence. In the endless blackness of the void, after an infinite amount of finite time, these thoughts coalesced into being. One being. This being, these illimitable emotions, wandered through the inky oblivion for perpetuity and timelessness, until it realized it was boundlessly and everlastingly alone. And so, from these thoughts, from this being, using all of its emotion, its soul; the purest form of magic, the universe exploded into existence, and with it, three fledgling gods were created from this incalculable eruption of sudden fervour, magic and soul: {@deity Angaradd|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight}, {@deity Auroril|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} and {@deity Melora|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight}. In the ever-expansive cosmic nebula, these four deities sailed the roiling cosmos, as The Lightbringer thought up a form for each of them to inhabit.

entries.name: Erestem's Influence
entries: Very few throughout Ilúvë have heard of The Lightbringer, and fewer still believe they even exist. Most lore and books of history have not stood the test of time, and therefore knowledge of The Lightbringer usually comes in the form of belief. The belief that life and light itself must be worshipped.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Those who believe in The Lightbringer believe his existance to be all-encompassing: a paradox of mind, body and soul; he is all, yet nothing. By all accounts, The Lightbringer's original form is believed to be a shapeless yet humanoid body of impossibly bright light, like a burning star. Followers of The Lightbringer carry small, featureless humanoid made of a white crystal (usually quartz), arms outstreched in an inviting manner.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: The Lightbringer's holy day is referred to as {@i Starfall}. During Starfall, followers of The Lightbringer gather at night to witness comet rains and the shifting of constellations, especially one named "Erestem's Belt". The night of Starfall is also a night of gift-giving and joy. It is often celebrated with omnipresent music in public areas, lavish gift-giving to relatives and loved ones, and the cutting and decorating of trees placed indoors. Because it is the peak of the winter season, devout followers of the Matron of Ravens consider it to be one of {@i her} holy days as well, as she is the goddess of winter.

items: Lead with mercy, patience, and compassion. Inspire others to unite in fellowship.
Aid those who are without guidance. Guide those without light. Heal those who are without hope.
Those who are beyond redemption, who revel in slaughter and remorseless evil, must be dispatched with swift justice.

entries.name: Piety
Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Erestem when you expand the god's influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Learning more about the world and the universe around you
Revealing a critical truth at an important moment
Keeping the order when no one else does
Aiding the weak or impeding the strong

entries: Your piety score to Erestem decreases if you diminish Erestem's influence in the world, upset the balance of power, or make him look biased or petty through acts such as these:

items: Giving into chaos and destruction
Rupturing or otherwise harming space-time
Furthering the aims of another god in defiance of Erestem's will

entries: Unlike other gods or lesser idols, Erestem is not a being that requires prayer or devotion, instead it simply is, a subject to be studied and to learn from.

items: {@reward Erestem's Devotee|WorldOfLight}
{@reward Erestem's Votary|WorldOfLight}
{@reward Erestem's Disciple|WorldOfLight}
{@reward Champion of Time|WorldOfLight}

deity.name: Angaradd
deity.title: God of Crafting, Creation and Smithing
deity.province: Creation, Crafting, Designing, Earth, Protection, Pride and Smithing

entries: Angaradd is worshiped by smiths, artisans, and miners alike, granting inspiration in exchange for respect and prayer. He shaped the mountains from the chaos of the Founding, and stands as the patron protector of home and family. The devotion to the All-Hammer is strongest in dwarven communities, and many temples to Angaradd mark the center of a mighty dwarven stronghold.

entries.name: Angaradd's Influence
entries: Angaradd is said to lord over the soul forges within the massive tunneled mansion of Erackinor, deep beneath the slopes of the mythical mountain of Abbathror; the afterlife most Dwarves could only hope to be rewarded with.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Many guild halls and workshops contain images of Angaradd, a faceless, stout dwarven being of immense strength, hunched over a flaming heart clasped within his massive hands.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Angaradd's holy day is Deep Solace, which is celebrated on the eighteenth day of the fifth month. Especially devout followers of the All-Hammer spend the day in isolation, meditating on the meaning of family and how they may be better mothers, fathers, siblings, and children. The dwarvish citadel of Dor Gonnoth celebrates with a full day of feasting and drinking.

items: Meet adversity with stoicism and tenacity.
Demonstrate loyalty to your family, your clan, your leaders, and your people.
Strive to make a mark on the world, a lasting legacy. To make something that lasts is the highest good, whether you are a smith working at a forge or a ruler building a dynasty.

deity.name: Auroril
deity.title: Goddess of The Skies, The Sun and Fire
deity.province: The Skies, The Sun, Fire, Summer and Agriculture

entries: Auroril rules over sun and summer, her vigil encircling the ages as the keeper of time. As queen of agriculture and harbinger of the harvest, she is worshiped by farmers and most common folk, and her priests are welcomed in many lands. Supporter of the needy and destroyer of evil, The Morning Song is often the patron of paladins and rangers who follow a similar creed. She is also known for her defeat of The Abyssal Coil and is revered by those who hunt aberrations.

entries.name: Auroril's Influence
entries: Auroril is often depicted within the Fortress of the Sun, a shining, golden citadel that is said to bring vibrant life to the burning Sun high in Ilúvë's sky.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Tapestries of old match early texts describing Auroril as a maternal figure in silver and gold armor, her head a beacon of light and fire so bright that her beautiful face can barely be seen. Many statues in holy places use the head as a brazier, lit with each dawn and extinguished at dusk.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Auroril's holy day is called Highsummer, and takes place on the fifteenth day of the seventh month. While other parts of Ilúvë feast, the Empire uses this day as an opportunity to enlist more soldiers in its army. The military holds great feasts and hands out toy soldiers and other propaganda, encouraging people to enlist and help fight against the evil that threatens the Emperor.

items: Alleviate suffering wherever you find it.
Bring Auroril’s light into places of darkness, showing kindness, mercy, and compassion.
Be watchful against evil.

deity.name: Erathis
deity.title: Goddess of Civilization and Invention
deity.symbol: Upper half of a clockwork gear

entries: The inspiration behind many great inventions, the creation of vast cities, and law and order within society, Erathis claims dominion over civilization. Judges and rulers pay respect at her temples, which are central structures in many cities across Ilúvë. Peace and order through structure and law guides the will of her devout followers. The Law Bearer has a tempestuous romance with {@deity Melora|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} the Wild Mother, a furious love that is tempered only when civilization and nature are in balance.

entries.name: Erathis' Influence
entries: Erathis is depicted within the glorious divine metropolis of Hestavar, the Bright City. This glowing oasis is said to be barely visible, almost like a distant reflection, in the astral sea, as the Law Bearer watches over the denizens bathed in the endless daytime that illuminates the busy streets.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Erathis is shown in most texts and statues as a hooded, armored woman sitting atop a throne of pillars. Her face is generally obscured or depicted without expression, giving her presence an impartial yet imposing nature.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: The Law Bearer's holy day is Civilization's Dawn, which is celebrated on the autumnal equinox, usually the twenty-second day of the ninth month. In the Empire, people celebrate by having feasts in honor of the laws set by the Inner Cabinet. One seat at every table is left open for the Emperor, who eats in spirit with the people he rules.

items: Work with others to achieve your goals. Community and order are always stronger than the disjointed efforts of lone individuals.
Tame the wilderness to make it fit for habitation, and defend the light of civilization against the encroaching darkness.
Seek out new ideas, new inventions, new lands to inhabit, new wilderness to conquer. Build machines, build cities, build empires.

deity.name: Melora
deity.title: Goddess of Wilderness and The Sea
deity.province: Beasts, Critters, Nature, Wilderness and The Sea

entries: The realm of Melora extends to wherever the seas shift and the land grows wild. As the keeper of the wilderness, Melora represents the wild creatures of nature, the rush of the angry rapids, and the heat-heavy stillness of the desert. Elves worship her, as do hunters, accepting her guidance to exist harmoniously within savage lands. Those seeking safe passage across dangerous waters pray to her to guide them.

Followers of the Raven Queen also show respect to the Wild Mother as the caretaker of what remains when the Matron of Death's work is done. Druids of Melora the Wild Mother and clerics of her lover, {@deity Erathis|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} the Law Bearer, work together to preserve the balance of nature and civilization. However, worship of Melora was outlawed in the Empire, causing disagreement between clerics of Erathis within The Bramble Downs, where many blame poor weather and natural disasters on the ire of their deity's partner.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Immortalized through wooden reliefs and carved idols in hidden, overgrown groves and rural shrines, the Wild Mother is shown as a beautiful woman with green skin nearly swallowed by a wild, tangled wreath of hair, leaves, and vines that dwarf her lithe form.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Melora's holy day is Wild's Grandeur, which is celebrated on the vernal equinox, usually the twentieth day of the third month. The people of the Stormkeep set aside this day to sail for no reason other than the pleasure of observing the natural beauty of their surroundings.

items: Protect the untamed wilderness from exploitation and destruction.
Slay abominations and other mockeries of nature.
Embrace and respect the savage nature of the world. Exist in harmony with it.

deity.name: Ioun
deity.title: Goddess of Knowledge and Magic
deity.province: Knowledge, Learning, Prophecy, Psionics and Magic
deity.symbol: Crook shaped like a stylized eye

entries: Revered by seers, sages, and teachers of all walks of life, Ioun guided the growth of civilization throughout the Age of Magicka like sunlight guides the branches of a tree. Grievously wounded by Ilbrant during the Dawn War, her followers are now hunted by agents of her ancient foes as she recovers. Her devout now worship in private, spreading knowledge, philosophy, and lore anonymously through traceless channels.

entries.name: Ioun's Influence
entries: Ioun is depicted among the infinite library that fills the mythical, hidden realm of the Endless Athenaeum, her celestial servants cataloging all known things as she inspires those who pray for her insight and guidance.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Common representations show the Knowing Mentor as a graying, mature woman with a welcoming, matronly smile, swathed in billowing robes and scarves that fan into books and scrolls. Some colloquially refer to Ioun as the Knowing Mistress, revering her as a headmistress of knowledge among the gods.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Ioun has no public holy day, for her public worship was shattered after the disappearance of The Chroniclers, and she has since fallen into half-remembered myth. Only in the monasteries of the Hand of Eon's Minute and The Red Tower has the Knowing Mentor's faith been resurrected—though her worship by the intellectuals of these places bears little resemblance to that of the knowledge-seekers of old.

items: Seek the perfection of your mind by bringing reason, perception, and emotion into balance with one another.
Accumulate, preserve, and distribute knowledge in all forms. Pursue education, build libraries, and seek out lost and ancient lore.
Be watchful at all times for the followers of Vecna, who seek to control knowledge and keep secrets. Oppose their schemes, unmask their secrets, and blind them with the light of truth and reason.

deity.name: Kord
deity.title: God of Storms
deity.province: Athletics, Bravery, Competition, Courage, Storms and Strength
deity.symbol: A wooden Buckler shield cracked with blue lightning

entries: Where thunder booms and conflict rises, prayers to the Storm Lord are shouted into the maelstrom. Reveling in all tests of strength, Kord blesses those who prove themselves on the battlefield. Worshiped by athletes and warriors all across Ilúvë, he exalts those whose force of spirit and desire for victory call his attention. He brings tumultuous storms over land and sea, and those who wish for clearer skies offer their praises and prayers to appease him.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Within his temples, Kord is shown as a quintessential warrior, often nude with a beard and short, curled hair. As the epitome of muscle and strength, most art depicts the Storm Lord in a stance of dominance, and perhaps wrestling a terrible beast.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Kord's holy day is the Day of Challenging, which is celebrated on the seventh day of the second month. The Day of Challenging is one of the most raucous holidays in Daggerford, and thousands of spectators attend the annual Godsbrawl held in the Temple of Kord to root for their favored deity's champion, particularly the chosen champions of the Storm Lord and the All-Hammer.

items: Bravery above all. There is no glory in cowardice.
Strength is the path to greatness, but greatness is the responsible use of strength.
The glory of the Storm Lord lives through your own glory on the battlefield.

deity.name: Sehanine
deity.title: Goddess of The Moons
deity.province: Autumn, Dreams, Illusion, Love, Moonlight, Night and The Moons

entries: Sehanine is the goddess of moonlight and the autumn season, as well as the patron of illusions and misdirection. Widely worshiped in halfling and elven cultures, she is considered to be the deity of love, protecting the trysts of lovers with shadows of her own making. Those who work in darkness and trickery often ask for her blessing.

entries.name: Sehanine's Influence
entries: Sehanine is said to loom over the skies of Ilúvë as the largest of the two moons, everwatchful that the moons and {@deity Auroril|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight}'s Sun don't collide.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: The Moon Weaver's depictions are as numerous as the myths and stories of her meddling with the unions of mortals. She is most often painted as a young girl with light-blue skin and white hair, her body and limbs merely wavy silk strands of silver moonlight that caress and create the edges of the shadows around her.
In the Feywild, however, especially there where day is, she is sometimes depicted as a bright red-haired female Ranger, referred to as Ehlonna.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Sehanine has no holy day but is celebrated by the elves on the night of the decade's largest full moon. Elven astronomers track the both of the moons' phases and how they grow closer and farther to Ilúvë to predict these days with great accuracy. Many haughty elves use this festival as an excuse to be sly and mischievous, while younger elves use costumes and illusions to prank their peers. Some elves of Sylingur hold a secret festival near The Cloakwood during the full moon, since the Empire doesn't allow worship of the Moon Weaver.

items: Follow your goals and seek your own destiny.
Keep to the shadows, avoiding the blazing light of zealous good and the utter darkness of evil.
Seek new horizons and new experiences, and let nothing tie you down.

deity.name: Bahamut
deity.title: God of Honor, Justice and Nobility
deity.province: Honor, Justice, Nobility and Protection

entries: Called the Platinum Justiciar, Bahamut is the god of justice, protection, nobility, and honor. Lawful good paladins often revere him, and metallic dragons worship him as the first of their kind. Monarchs are crowned in his name. The crest of the Platinum Dragon adorns many halls of high leadership and justice, invoking his will in all matters of justice. To follow him is to look after those who cannot look after themselves.

In ancient times, Bahamut was widely worshipped by elves, but by a name now mostly forgotten; Xymor. In fact, the ancient elves had a tendancy to worship gods for aspects they do not directly hold dominion over, and Xymor was no different, having Courtship and Battle under his gleaming wings as well.

entries.name: Bahamut's Influence
entries: Bahamut is depicted to reside within his magnificent, glittering palace of gold, platinum, and mithril, known as the Govoldeim Palace.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: The Platinum Dragon is often seen emblazoned on shields and armor, both functional and decorative, in the form of a brilliant dragon head in profile. Temples and works of art depict a massive, glittering dragon with vibrant platinum scales and seemingly endless wingspan.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Bahamut's holy day is called Embertide, and is celebrated on the fifth day of Duscar. This is a day of remembrance, solemnity, and respect for those who have fallen in the defense of others.

items: Uphold the highest ideals of honor and justice.
Be constantly vigilant against evil and oppose it on all fronts.
Protect the weak, liberate the oppressed, and defend just order.

deity.name: Corellon
deity.title: God of Music and Wisdom
deity.province: Art, Beauty, Music, Poetry, Spring, Wisdom and Warfare

entries: Guardian of art, spring, beauty, and wisdom, Corellon is the patron of the fey. Cast into the world to fight Tharizdun head-on, he seeded the world with wisdom, while raising the most ancient of forests. It was by the Arch Heart's hand that the first elves wandered from the Feywild, and for this reason they are considered the Mother and Father of all elves. Oft called the "Third Dragon", it is a well-establish fact that Corellon took inspiration from Ioun and Angaradd, creating the psionic Gem dragons. Those who seek art in all their work often worship at the altar of Corellon. They loathe the Spider Queen and her priestesses for leading the drow astray.
Many elf wizards honor Corellon and adorn their spellbooks and towers with the god's symbols.

entries.name: Corellon's Influence
entries: Corellon watches the business of mortals and gods from within the palace of Crescent Grove, a grove depicted as being surrounded by towering white trees and pillars of marble.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Most modern tapestries and tomes depict the Arch Heart as an elven being of impossible grace and beauty, androgynous and alluring, framed by long, wavy, golden hair. They were the inspiration for many early elven art pieces, and elements of their visage or symbol are included in most elven architecture.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Corellon's holy day is called Elvendawn, or Midsummer. It is celebrated on the twentieth day of the sixth month, and commemorates the elves' first emergence from the Feywild. Though the Empire doesn't promote the worship of the Archheart, many elves within Sylingur quietly celebrate in private by opening small doors to the Feywild and having a little more wine than usual.

items: Cultivate beauty in all that you do, whether you’re casting a spell, composing a saga, strumming a lute, or practicing the arts of war.
Seek out lost magic items, forgotten rituals, and ancient works of art. Corellon might have inspired them in the world’s first days.
Thwart the followers of Lolth at every opportunity.

entries.name: The Blessed of Corellon
entries: Ever changing, mirthful, and beautiful, the primal elves could assume whatever sex they liked. When they bowed to Lolth's influence and chose to fix their physical forms, elves lost the ability to transform in this way. Yet occasionally elves are born who are so androgynous that they are proclaimed to be among the blessed of Corellon-living symbols of the god's love and of the primal elves' original fluid state of being. Many of Corellon's chief priests bear this blessing.

The rarest of these blessed elves can change their sex whenever they finish a long rest-a miracle celebrated by elves of all sorts except drow. (The DM decides whether an elf can manifest this miracle.) Dark elves find this ability to be terrifying and characterize it as a curse, for it could destabilize their entire society. If Corellon's blessing manifests in a drow, that elf usually flees to the surface world to seek shelter among those dedicated to Corellon.

deity.name: Takhisis
deity.title: Goddess of Greed and Revenge
deity.province: Chromatic Dragons, Greed, Hatred, Nightmares and Revenge

entries: The evil queen of dragons is a fearsome god of greed, envy, and hoarded wealth. While chromatic dragons are her foremost worshipers, Takhisis accepts the worship of any who crave wealth. All chromatic dragons have a fearful reverence for their tyrannical queen, but many dragons of near-deific power and ambition chafe under her rule.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Most representations of Takhisis exist as warnings within sanctuaries of the Platinum Justiciar. She is shown as a drake of frightful size, with massive leathery wings spreading clouds of poisonous mist, while she shouts from five vicious dragon heads, each one a chromatic color of her evil children.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: The Scaled Tyrant's hatred for {@deity Bahamut|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} is as old as the Creation, and her cults are ever hunted by his justice. For centuries, the zealous paladins of Bahamut have limited her worship to the chromatic dragons, but a rise in cult activity in the underbelly of Arcaborian society has priests of the Platinum Justiciar on edge.

items: Amass wealth, but spend little. The gold—and the power that comes with it—is sufficient reward in itself.
Do not forgive nor forget an indignity to yourself. Let no affront go unpunished.
Take what you covet. Those without the strength to defend their dominion are not worthy to have one.

deity.name: Tharizdun
deity.title: Deity of Decay and Madness
deity.province: Annihalation, Entropy, Eternal Darkness, Decay, Insanity and Ruination

entries: Tharizdun is darkness unending. Less like a god and more like another world. Life and death do not exist within Tharizdun, only utter destruction and madness. Even the other Interloper gods, gods that were spat out by the roiling madness, treat their creator with caution. In its endless imprisonment, Tharizdun dreams the infinite depths of the Abyss into reality, along with all its demonic legions. The gods of light had unwillingly brought it upon the realms during the creation, until it nearly returned to ruin the world during the conflicts of the Age of Assault.

Now, its chaotic mind has fallen into more frightful dreams, imagining nightmarish aberrations into existence deep beneath Ilúvë. Tharizdun's demented cultists work without word from their twisted patron, awaiting the Epoch of Ends, when its freedom will be attained and all beings shall be consumed in the endless, inky void of oblivion.

entries.name: Tharizdun's Influence
entries: Tharizdun, being something far more powerful than the gods, is believed to be chained in the deepest pits of the Abyss, bound by divine shackles that slowly weaken, leaking its madness into the planes.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Few visual attempts to depict Tharizdun exist, but the texts speak of a creature of rolling, hungry ink, gnashing teeth and darkness, a spreading cloud of lightless destruction born from a thousand ravenous mouths. Current references show the nightmare constrained by chains of gold and black, barely keeping the dark at bay.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: The few remaining followers of Ioun are dedicated to ensuring that Tharizdun is never again unchained. Ioun led the charge against the all-consuming destroyer god's reemergence, and her bravery allowed the other Prime Deities to shackle their enemy, though the victory nearly cost her immortal life. Some say Ioun can only be fully restored if the The Unending Darkness is destroyed for good.

items: Offer and siphon power to Tharizdun until his liberation comes.
Uncover, restore, and exalt forgotten shrines and relics in his honor.
Ruin and raze the realms to prepare for the Epoch of Ends.

deity.name: Hextor
deity.title: God of War and Conquest
deity.province: Conflict, Conquest, Discord, Massacres and War

entries: Blood-drenched armies of brutal warriors oft crush their foes in the name of Hextor, the evil patron of war and conquest. To serve his will is to accept the call to conflict, seeking lesser people to break and subjugate. Warmongering nations and goblinoid tribes worship the Scourger as they strike out at the world to bend it beneath them. Hextor twists all living things to his iron will, forcing even nature itself to bow to his whims.

entries.name: Hextor's Influence
entries: Hextor plots his conquest from within the bastion of Banehold.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Hextor is often depicted as a hideous, gray skinned, six-armed humanoid bearing two large tusks jutting from its lower jaw wearing armor clad with skulls. He wields a weapon in each hand: a spiked flail, a battle axe, a battle pick, a longsword, a mace, and a falchion.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: The Scourger's greatest enemy is Melora, who defeated him at Icegale Ridge during the Dawn War. The Scourger grew his armies by corrupting noble creatures into monsters and destroying the wilds to fuel his terrible engines of conflict, and the two deities clashed many times during the war before his defeat at Helm's Hand.

items: Never allow your fear to gain mastery over you, but drive it into the hearts of your foes.
Punish insubordination and disorder.
Hone your combat skills to perfection, whether you are a mighty general or a lone mercenary.

deity.name: Vecna
deity.title: God of Secrets
deity.province: Evil, Coveting, Dark Magic, Hoarding, Secrets and Undeath

entries: Vecna is the evil god of undead, necromancy, and secrets. He rules that which is not meant to be known and that which people wish to keep secret. Vecna is considered the most powerful and the most evil lich in history. He rose to godhood, becoming the god of secrets.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Those who claim to have looked on Vecna's form speak of a tall, skeletal lich swathed in tattered robes and enchanted jewels, missing both his left hand and left eye.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: While Vecna loathes all other gods and wishes to destroy them and become the sole divine power in the planes, he has a particular hatred for {@deity Ioun|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight}. Ioun seeks to share with the world the same secrets Vecna guards for himself, and his followers have worked diligently to undermine and destroy the Library of the Chroniclers and any others who follow her path. The Raven Queen also despises Vecna, and sees his presence as a mighty affront to her purpose.

items: Learn all you can, and keep hidden that which you know. Reveal what pieces you must, but never the whole.
Express and cultivate the evil within yourself, and in doing so, recognize it in others to exploit them for your own benefit.
Seed the ruin of all who worship other deities, until only those who kneel before Vecna remain.

deity.name: Zehir
deity.title: God of Darkness and Poison
deity.province: Assassins, Darkness, Thievery, Poison and Snakes
deity.symbol: Snake in the shape of a dagger

entries: A wanderer in the shadows and the creator of snakes and serpentkin, Zehir is the evil god of poisons, assassins, and darkness. The ancient serpentkin worship him over all other deities, dragging screaming offerings to their temples in his honor. Most of the Midnight Serpent's worshipers were annihilated during the Dawn War, however recently Zehir has started to gain more prominence after re-emerging as a god worshipped by the Ashen Drow of Nordabȧd.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Many forgotten temples were once built to the Cloaked Serpent, and within these chambers his image was embedded within much of the architecture. He is shown as a human body with six arms and a gargantuan serpentine head, fanged and frilled in aggression. Strands of thick, dark hair that sprout from his scaled body form layers of swirling shadow, obscuring his form.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: Zehir loathes {@deity Erathis|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} and {@deity Melora|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight}, for he despises life, order, and love above all things. His surviving worshipers use poison and fire to undermine civilization and consume nature, hoping to infuriate both gods and cast Ilúvë into chaos.

items: Hide under the cloak of night, that your deeds might be kept in secret.
Kill in Zehir's name and offer each murder as a sacrifice.
Delight in poison, and surround yourself with snakes.

deity.name: Gruumsh
deity.title: God of Destruction and Murder
deity.province: Carnage, Destruction, Hunting, Pillaging, Savageness, Slaughter, Warmongering
deity.symbol: Grey triangular eye with bony protrusions

entries: Gruumsh commands hordes of barbaric marauders to destroy, pillage, and slaughter for the sheer joy of it. Orderless and without honor, the creeds of the evil hordemaster urge savage creatures to devour the world around them, giving in to the chaotic and selfish nature of the predator. A number of violent clans of humanoids and beasts across Nordurvilt pay homage to Gruumsh, asking him to bless their hunts and gift them with spoils worth ruining.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Primitive clay representations in barbaric communities of his followers show the Ruiner as a hulking, bulbous behemoth of an orc. His missing eye has shifted, and the prominent eye is now centered in his face, like a nightmarish cyclops.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: Corellon shot out Gruumsh's right eye during the Age of Assault, and the god of slaughter longs for the day he can return the favor twofold. Those who serve the Ruiner are sometimes hypnotized by his hateful rage from across the Divine Gate and fall into a strange bloodlust, longing to slaughter elves and those who worship magic at the altar of the Archheart.

items: Ruin. Conquer. Kill.
The weak exist to be crushed by the strong. Be the strong.
There are no emotions but fury and joy. The rest are weakness.

deity.name: Lolth
deity.title: Goddess of Spiders and Lies
deity.province: Deceit, Drow, Lies, Lust, Shadows, Spiders and Women

entries: The evil goddess of deceit, shadows, and spiders, the Spider Queen weaves a complicated web of schemes and treachery through her worshipers, deceiving allies and enemies alike to gain power. The Spider Queen's worship is entwined with the society of dark elves, even as the drow fall ever deeper into the thrall of the The Unending Darkness's aberrant minions. It is said that the Spider Queen can see through the eyes of all spiders, and that she is truly all-knowing.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Many Lolthite icons and idols show an alluring woman with dark purple skin and silver hair, her abdomen swelling into the terrifying body of a monstrous spider.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: Lolth holds a searing grudge against Kord, the Storm Lord, for with one throw of his mighty thunderspear he impaled her against a cliffside, leaving her drow armies leaderless during the Dawn War. Lolth and Gruumsh also share a burning hatred for Corellon, whom she claims drove her children below the earth, and Lolth often manipulates Gruumsh's followers into attacking her enemies so that the drow may remain safe.

items: Misdirection, slander, and shadowed steps have more function than direct conflict.
It is better to be loved than feared, but you may certainly try to be both.
Death to the elves who live under the sun, and death to all their allies!

deity.name: Nera
deity.title: Goddess of Death, Fate and Winter
deity.province: Death, Fate, Winter and Mortality

entries: She is the spinner of fate and the patron of winter. She marks the end of each mortal life, and mourners call upon her during funeral rites, in the hope that she will guard the departed from the curse of undeath.

entries.name: The Raven Queen's Influence
entries: The Raven Queen tugs at the threads of fate from her stronghold of black ice within the frozen realm of Letherna.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Few existing visual depictions of the Raven Queen exist; many temples merely use the raven as a symbol of her blessing. The few illustrations of her portray a tall, pale, gaunt woman wrapped in dangling black linens, with her face obscured by a white porcelain mask and her onyx-black hair straight and neverending.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: The Raven Queen's holy day is called the Night of Ascension, celebrated on the thirteenth day of the tenth month.

items: Death is the natural end of life. There is no pity for those who have fallen.
The path of Fate is sacrosanct. Those who pridefully attempt to cast off their destiny must be punished.
Undeath is an atrocity. Those who would pervert the transition of the soul must be brought down.

deity.name: Torog
deity.title: God of Enslavement and Pain
deity.province: The Underdark, Enslavement, Imprisonment, Pain and Torture
deity.symbol: Letter "T" attached to a circular shackle

entries: The dark god of the endless tunnels and caverns beneath Ilúvë, Torog is the patron of torturers, slavers, and jailers across the realms. His violent tears carved the pathways under the world, and his realm of imprisonment is a network of deadly caves and manacles from which few return. Creatures that wander the desolation of Carceri often construct prisons in his image. Those who rob others of their freedom offer prayers to him in cellars and other subterranean domains, and many creatures who live in the darkness below worship him and seek his guidance.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: The Crawling King is rendered as a swollen, malformed worm that slithers through the dark below, with a screaming, hairless human head at the helm and three arms carving through the lightless rock.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: {@deity Auroril|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} and {@deity Corellon|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} defeated Torog during the Age of Assault by luring their nemesis above ground. Auroril pierced Torog's tenebrous body with ten thousand lances of sunlight, and Corellon imprisoned him beyond the boundaries of Ilúvë. The tears of pain and anger the Crawling King shed burned through Ilúvë, and his faithful fled into these tunnels to escape their enemies' holy light.

items: Seek and exalt places where no light touches.
Revel in the pain you inflict on others, and relish the pain you suffer yourself as an offering to Torog.
Imprison those who cannot resist you, and drag all life into the darkness.

deity.name: The Strangers
deity.title: Deity of Balance, Chaos and Chance

entries: After the Age of Assault, The Lightbringer, in his endless sorrow, unknowingly seeded the world with malice and despair. In an act of desperation, in order to preserve the world of light, Erestem's children pulled a spirit from the given world. What they could not have forseen, was the spirit's twin following after. Together, these two became newly born trickster gods, by the name of Dubhgall and Finngaill, and became one. Using their learned tricks to misdirect and fool, they lightened Erestem's sorrow.

Bound together as brothers, The Strangers find pleasure in mischief and compete for dominance—something their followers describe as feeling like a tug of war within their own heads. To them, mortals are neither good nor evil, and so everyone is fair game. Though seen as naïve by the other gods—gaining notoriety with Nera and Vecna, whom both describe them as "immature fools", especially Nera who see their acts of unpredictability to be an insult to her existence—The Strangers are clever and cunning.

Followers of The Strangers include tricksy Clerics, Rogues and Bards with a penchant for chaos. Followers typically carry a blank coin that they flip to help decide their actions, not knowing which side is good or bad. The Strangers will push their followers to lights and extremes, further solidifying the mental tug of war the trickster deity poses upon them.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: The Strangers are usually depicted as two hooded figures, one smiling, the other frowning. Statues depicting The Strangers are far and few between, though particularly pious temples depict statues of The Strangers as a single entity; one usually veiled behind a deck of cards.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: The Strangers' holy day, called New Dawn, takes place on the first day of the first month, when the old year gives way to the new. In the Bramble Downs, people celebrate by having a feast on the shore near Port Delthuntle at dusk to watch the sunset. They feast and discuss their hopes for the new year until the sun rises.

items: Luck favors the bold. Your fate is your own to grasp, and to do so is to have The Strangers behind you.
Change is inevitable. The righteous can ensure that such change is for the better.
Rise against tyranny. Fight for the freedom of yourself and others when you can, and inspire others to fight when you cannot.

deity.name: Selûne
deity.title: Goddess of The Moons, Mystery and Shadows
deity.province: Moons, Mystery, Shadows and Love

entries: An ancient form of Sehanine, worshipped as the primal essence of the Moons. Believed to be a wielder of the "moonbow", Selûne depicts a much more primal and stern goddess. These parts of her are still widely worshipped, and even Sehanine's afterlife still resides on an infinite sea with a single tower, named the Tower of Selûne.
During the time of the Hastilude, Selûne plays a pivotal role in the lives of many surface Drow, looking to be absolved of what their ancestors did in ages past.

deity.name: Narallin
deity.title: God of Economics and Wealth
deity.province: Economy, Wealth, Laws, Greed and Jewelry
deity.symbol: Gold Necklace with large Ashy-Grey Gem

entries: In the annals of elven history, one finds traces of Narallin, the enigmatic God of Economics and Wealth. Narallin is a deity of a bygone era, celebrated in ancient elven society as the embodiment of capitalism and the chaotic ebb and flow of wealth. His influence was felt most keenly during an age when the elves pursued not only mastery over nature but also mastery over the intricate dance of coins and commerce.

Though Narallin's influence waned as elven society evolved and shifted its priorities, his legacy endures in the form of ancient contracts, hidden vaults of forgotten treasures, and the intricate financial systems that underpin elven society. Some contemporary elves view him with reverence, while others see him as a symbol of avarice and excess.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Narallin is oft depicted as an elf of regal bearing, draped in red robes adorned with golden threads and precious gemstones. His eyes sparkle with the unmistakable gleam of a shrewd negotiator, and his fingers bear the weight of countless signet rings. In his right hand, he holds a set of unbalanced scales, forever tipping, while his left hand clutches a sack overflowing with coins, usually punctured, leaving wealth wherever he walks.

deity.name: Elanarë
deity.title: Goddess of Fire and War
altNames: The Knight of Wing and Flame
deity.province: War, Fire, Rebirth and The Sun

entries: According to elven legend, the ancient Goddess Elenarë birthed the first phoenix, a symbol of rebirth and renewal from the ashes of destruction. It is said that from the flames of her fury, she shaped the first humans, instilling in them the fiery spirit of determination and resilience. Thus, humans are considered the children of Elenarë, born in the crucible of war.

Elenarë's domain encompasses not only the destructive forces of war but also the transformative power of fire, and the ever-flowing passage of time. She was believed to have guided elven armies with her fiery wisdom, blessing their blades and inspiring valor in the heat of battle. Her temples served as forges, where weapons and artifacts were crafted, and where elven blacksmiths sought her blessing for their finest works.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Elenarë is oft depicted as a radiant elven warrior, her form bathed in the flickering light of eternal flames. She dons armor crafted from solid gold, with a helm that resembles the majestic crest of a phoenix. Her eyes burn with the intensity of a roaring inferno, and her hair flows like bursts of sunlight.

deity.name: Alkenstar
deity.title: Deity of Torture, Death, Darkness and Disease
deity.province: Torture, Death, Darkness, Disease and Void
deity.symbol: Burning black skull or Sickly gray four-pointed Star

entries: Alkenstar is a deity shrouded in dread, a being of unfathomable darkness and despair. Revered with fearful whispers, Alkenstar represents the unsettling and malevolent aspects of existence: torture, death, darkness, and disease. In the history books of elven lore, Alkenstar is the embodiment of all that the elves once feared and could not comprehend.

The worship of Alkenstar is not one of devotion, but of fearful reverence. In ancient times, some elves turned to Alkenstar out of desperation, beseeching the deity for mercy or protection from the horrors of existence. Others sought to placate Alkenstar's wrath by offering sacrifices, hoping to avert the malevolent gaze of this enigmatic deity.

While Alkenstar is no longer widely worshipped among the elves, its legacy endures as a symbol of the deepest, darkest aspects of existence. It serves as a haunting reminder that in the ever-evolving tapestry of the cosmos, there are forces that defy understanding and challenge even the most resolute of faiths.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Alkenstar is often depicted as a vaguely humanoid figure cloaked in impenetrable shadow, with eyes that burn like the void itself. Its form is ever-shifting, a grotesque fusion of torment and decay. It is said that gazing upon Alkenstar's true visage can drive mortals to madness.

deity.name: Null Rancaria
deity.title: Goddess of Fear, Fate, Mindlessness and Eternal Damnation
deity.province: Fear, Fate, Mindlessness, Eternal Damnation, Secrets and Dark Magic
deity.symbol: Blood-red Sigil in the vauge shape of an N

entries: Null Rancaria is a deity of unrelenting terror and despair, a name whispered only in the darkest corners of elven history. She is the embodiment of all that the elves dare not confront: fear, fate, mindlessness, eternal damnation, secrets, and the darkest strains of dark magic. Her worship is considered anathema, for it invites a malevolent presence that few mortals can withstand.

To utter the name of Null Rancaria is to invoke an omen of desolation and despair. It is a name that brings ill fortune and dread, a harbinger of calamity. The elves, in their wisdom, have stricken her name from their tongues, fearing that mere mention would draw her sinister attention.

Those who delve into her mysteries risk becoming vessels of unspeakable malevolence, wielding power that can rend the fabric of reality. Her name is synonymous with fear itself. She serves as a haunting reminder to the elves that there are depths of dread that should never be explored. Her legacy endures as a cautionary tale. A deity of the most profound and inescapable terror.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Null Rancaria exists as a shadowy, formless void; an indistinct presence that defies mortal comprehension. Those who claim to have glimpsed her visage speak of eyes that pierce the soul and a voice that chills the blood. Her form is ever-shifting, a manifestation of fear itself.

deity.name: Morvael
deity.title: God Invention, Science, Evolution, and Ingenuity
deity.province: Invention, Science, Evolution, and Ingenuity
deity.symbol: An Arcane Orb made of Brass

entries: Morvael is a deity shrouded in the mysteries of invention and the pursuit of knowledge. According to elven lore, Morvael is revered as the God of Invention, Science, Evolution, and Ingenuity. Yet, few outside the clandestine circles of the Arcanixian wizards are aware of this deity's existence, for the Arcanixians believed themselves above the influence of the gods.

Morvael encompasses the relentless pursuit of knowledge, the transformative power of science, and the boundless ingenuity of invention. The Arcanixian wizards, in secret reverence, sought Morvael's guidance in their quest to unravel the deepest mysteries of the universe. Morvael is the keeper of secrets, the deity who guards the wisdom of ages past and the possibilities of ages to come. Those who venerated Morvael believed that through the pursuit of knowledge and the application of science, they could transcend the limitations of mortals and shape their own destiny.
Though the Arcanixians themselves may have believed they were above the gods, they unknowingly paid homage to Morvael with their ceaseless drive to push the boundaries of knowledge and technology.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Morvael is often depicted as a figure of unparalleled intellect, with eyes that shimmer with boundless curiosity. Dressed in robes of ever-changing colors (though preferring shades of blue), Morvael embodies the spirit of innovation and discovery. The deity's hands are forever busy, crafting intricate devices and unlocking the secrets of the cosmos.

deity.name: Teluniél
deity.title: Goddess of Beasts, Nature, Storms, and Vengeance
deity.province: Beasts, Nature, Storms, and Vengeance
deity.symbol: A hunting bow with four arrows

entries: Teluniél is the guardian of all creatures that roam the untamed forests and the vast wilderness. Elves who revere her seek her blessing when embarking on hunts or when seeking to establish harmony with the animal kingdom. Her guidance ensures that the delicate balance between hunter and prey is maintained. As the Avenger of the Natural World, Teluniél is invoked by those who seek retribution against those who defile the wilderness, exploit its resources, or harm its creatures. She is both a protector and a punisher, ensuring that those who harm nature face the consequences of their actions.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Teluniél is often depicted as a radiant elven huntress, her hair intertwined with leaves and her eyes reflecting the colors of the stormy sky. She is adorned with the pelts and feathers of wild creatures, and her outstretched arms are capable of conjuring tempests and summoning the fiercest of beasts.

feat.name: Thaumaturgic Expert
entries: Through your repeated exposure of the natural flow of arcane magic throughout Ilúvë, you've adapted to attune with additional enchantments, though the process can by physically taxing. You gain the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) checks when investigating the nature of a magical object or device.
You can attune to a maximum of four magical items, rather than the normal limit of three. Other attunement limitations still apply.

feat.name: Arcanixian Celerity
entries: Through intense focus, training, and dedication, you've unlocked what even some of the mages of Arcanix would have dreamed of; you have harnessed the techniques of rapid spellcasting.
You are no longer limited to only one non-cantrip spell per turn. However, should you cast two or more spells in a single turn, only one of them can be of 3rd level or higher.

entries.name: Rules Tip: Casting Multiple Spells
entries: Normally, when you cast a spell as a bonus action, you can't use your action to also cast a spell that turn unless that spell is a cantrip—{@note see {@book PHB p202|PHB|10|Bonus Action}.} The Spelldriver feat removes that restriction, but the focus necessary to channel multiple spells in the same round still limits the overall power of those spells.

feat.name: Nocturnal
entries: Due to extensive exposure to the dark, and possible supernatural abilities, you have an unmatched ability to fight adversaries in the dark. You gain the following benefits:

items: You gain Darkvision with a radius of 60 feet. If you already have darkvision, then the radius of your darkvision increases by 30 feet, to a maximum of 120 feet.
You have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks while in dim light or nonmagical darkness.
You can try to hide when you are lightly obscured from the creature from which you are hiding.
When you are hidden from a creature and miss it with a ranged weapon attack, making the attack doesn't reveal your position.
Dim light doesn't impose disadvantage on your Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks relying on sight.

entries: {@i NOTE: This feat replaces the Skulker feat.}

feat.name: Mending Affinity
entries: Your body has begun to adapt extremely well to healing itself through extraordinary means, gifting you the following benefits:

items: When a creature uses a {@item healer's kit|WorldOfLight} to stabilize you when you are dying, you also regain hit points equal to your proficiency modifier.
Whenever you regain hit points as a result of a spell, potion, or class ability, you regain additional hit points equal to your proficiency modifier.

feat.name: Mystic Channeling
entries: Countless hours have been spent training your mind to maintain focus on concurrent incantations, taxing as the process may be.

items: If you attempt to cast a spell that requires concentration while already concentrating on an existing spell, you can maintain concentration on both spells simultaneously.
If you take damage during this time, you must make a concentration check for each spell individually.

At the end of each turn where you have two spells you are concentrating on, you must make a Constitution saving throw (DC equals 8 + both spells' levels combined). On a success, you maintain concentration on both spells. On a failure, you lose concentration on both spells.

feat.name: Thrown Arms Master
entries: You've honed your ability to lob weaponry into the fray, including weapons not meant for ranged combat. You gain the following benefits:

items: Simple and martial melee weapons without the thrown property can be treated as if they have the thrown property. One-handed weapons have a range of 20/60, while two-handed weapons have a range of 15/30.
Weapons that naturally have the thrown property increase their range by +20/+40.
When you miss with a thrown weapon attack using a {@i light} weapon, the weapon immediately boomerangs back into your grasp.

feat.name: Spell Pugilist
entries: Thanks to extensive practice with ranged spellcasting and its limitations, you gain the following benefits:

items: Before you make a ranged spell attack with a spell you know, you can choose to take a -5 penalty to the attack roll. If the attack hits, you add +10 to the spell's damage.
Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged spell attack rolls.
If you make a ranged spell attack roll and hit the target, you can disengage as a bonus action.

feat.name: Martial Prestige

other: At least 3 levels in the Barbarian, Fighter, Monk or Rogue class.

entries: You are considered a paragon of your class, a formidable foe, and an even greater ally. You choose one subclass from (one of) your class's list, from among the Barbarian, Fighter, Monk or Rogue, and gain it's level 3 feature(s). If you choose a subclass that grants you the spellcasting feature, you are considered a 3rd-level caster for the purposes of this feat (meaning your spellcasting feature does not improve as you gain levels in the class).

item.name: Brigandine Armor
entries: A brigandine is a form of body armour. It is a garment, generally heavy cloth, canvas or leather, lined with small oblong steel plates riveted to the fabric.

item.name: Aegis of Radiance
entries: This golden shield emits a faint, holy glow when wielded and recognizes your devotion to a higher power. When you attune to this shield, the emblem adorning its face changes to one that represents your chosen deity, allowing you to use the shield as a holy symbol. You gain a +1 bonus to your AC while wielding this shield in addition to the shield's normal bonus to AC.

While wielding the shield, you can speak its command word as a bonus action to cause it to shatter into countless fragments of pure light. The pieces of light protect you as if you were wielding the shield, leaving your hands free. The light surrounds you for 1 minute, until you dismiss the effect as a bonus action, or until you fall unconscious or die, at which point the shield rematerializes on the ground at your feet or into your hand if you have one free. If your holy symbol is emblazoned or attached to the shield, it floats prominently amidst the shards of light and continues to function as a spellcasting focus. Undead creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls made against you while you're surrounded by the light in this way. The surrounding shards of light cast bright light in a 20 foot radius and dim light for another 20 feet. Once this property has been used, it can't be used again until the following dawn.

item.name: Band of Loyalty
entries: If you are reduced to zero hit points while attuned to a band of loyalty, you instantly die. These rings are favored by spies who can't afford to fall into enemy hands.

item.name: Dawnsteel
item.reqAttune: by a cleric, paladin or warlock
entries: This enchanted weapon has taken multiple forms across the ages, the most prominent of which a longsword. This blade was created by a disciple of {@deity Auroril|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} and breathed into existence by a most mighty mount; an ancient Phoenix by the name of {@i Lucernia}.
You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls you make with this magic weapon. This weapon deals an additional 1d8 radiant damage to undead.

When you kill an undead with this magic weapon, roll {@dice 1d10}. If you roll a 1 or 2, the undead's body bursts into blue flame that deals 2d8 fire damage to all undead within 10 feet of it. The flame does no damage and produces no noticeable heat to other types of creatures. If you are proficient with either Longswords, Greatswords, Rapiers and Shortswords, you are proficient with Dawnfang.

item.name: Gilded Bell of Arcanix
entries: This bell was used as a last-ditch effort to push back the forces of Thalor Ancalen during the Crown Wars. It was enchanted by the great Sage and Seer known as Azura Denduledáin, and was lost during the Crown Wars. It now bears little resemblance to the ancient enchantment used, as the residual magic of Arcanix has twisted it's very nature.

As an action, you can shake this small magical bell, causing the bell to make a faint twinkling sound. When you do so, the DM rolls randomly on the Gilded Bell table, and causes a small magical wonder.
Once you've used this feature, it can't be used until the next dawn.

item.name: The Brilliant Blade
entries: Crafted from the finest Elven steel and enchanted by the great Arch-Sorcerer Robin, this blade exudes perfection in every aspect, from the grooves of the leather-bound grip to the intricate elven carvings across the blade's surface, which read: "{@i For the Queens. For the King. For Thalor Ancalen.}".
You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls you make with this magic weapon. This weapon has a cool hex-casting ability, that shoots magic lol

item.name: Cenotaph
entries: Made of an exquisite Elven steel, this greatsword bears a beautiful handle made from solid gold. A blade fit for a king, the pommel contains a singular, large pink diamond, and embedded into the blade sit five dazzling gems.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls you make with this magic weapon. In addition, you have resistance to force damage while you wield this blade.

entries.name: Arcane Barrage
entries: The five gems embedded within this sword each contain a charge (for a total of five charges). As an action, whenever you hold this weapon, you can use one or more of the charges from them to cast the magic missile spell. For each charge above the first, the spell's level increases by 1.
Any expended charges replenish daily at midnight.

entries.name: Knowledge of Arcanix
entries: While you are attuned to this weapon, you gain a +2 bonus to Intelligence ({@skill History}) and Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) checks.

entries.name: Sentience and Personality
entries: Entrapped within this blade is the soul of Rhoderihck Johannez, making this weapon a neutral evil sentient weapon with an Intelligence of 14, a Wisdom of 18, and a Charisma of 22. It has hearing and {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet. It also has {@sense truesight} out to a range of 15 feet.

The sword can speak, read, and understand {@language Arconic|WorldOfLight}, {@language Common}, {@language Elvish}, {@language Draconic} and {@language Primordial}, and it can communicate with its wielder telepathically. Its voice is sly and impatient. It also knows every language you know while attuned to it.

Forged by the Arch-Sorcerer Alzatar Lefay, and trapped in the blade by Morgana Umbrind, Rhoderihck feels great resentment for his Phoenix Twelve members betraying him. Though he is neutral evil, he does take a quick liking to smart wielders.

item.name: Rhoderihck's Bag of Holding
entries: This bag belonged to Rhoderihck Johannez of Arcanix II, and has an interior space considerably larger than its outside dimensions, roughly 4 feet in diameter at the mouth and 8 feet deep. The bag can hold up to 1000 pounds, not exceeding a volume of 128 cubic feet. The bag weighs 20 pounds, regardless of its contents. Retrieving an item from the bag requires an action.

If the bag is overloaded, pierced, or torn, it ruptures and is destroyed, and its contents are scattered in the Astral Plane. If the bag is turned inside out, its contents spill forth, unharmed, but the bag must be put right before it can be used again. Breathing creatures inside the bag can survive up to a number of minutes equal to 10 divided by the number of creatures (minimum 1 minute), after which time they begin to suffocate.

Placing a bag of holding inside an extradimensional space created by a {@item Heward's handy haversack}, {@item portable hole}, or similar item instantly destroys both items and opens a gate to the Astral Plane. The gate originates where the one item was placed inside the other. Any creature within 10 feet of the gate is sucked through it to a random location on the Astral Plane. The gate then closes. The gate is one-way only and can't be reopened.

item.name: Runestone, Necrotic
entries: This small runestone seems suffused with a strange energy.

As a bonus action, you can throw this stone toward one creature of your choice within 60 feet of you. You are considered proficient in this item when you throw it, and you may choose either dexterity, strength, intelligence or wisdom as the modifier used in the attack roll. On a hit, the stone deals necrotic damage equal to {@damage 3d12} + your Dexterity, Strength, Intelligence or Wisdom modifier (your choice), and is destroyed upon impact.

item.name: Runestone, Brisingr
entries: This small runestone seems suffused with malicious energy.

As a bonus action, you can throw this stone toward one creature of your choice within 60 feet of you. You are considered proficient in this item when you throw it, and you may choose either dexterity, strength, intelligence or wisdom as the modifier used in the attack roll. On a hit, the stone deals fire or necrotic damage (your choice) equal to {@damage 3d12} + your Dexterity, Strength, Intelligence or Wisdom modifier (your choice), and is destroyed upon impact.

Alternatively, you can use a bonus action to crush the stone in your palm, dealing {@dice 4d6} necrotic damage to you, and radiating out a shockwave of hellish energy. Any creature within 20 feet of you must make a DC 16 dexterity saving throw, dealing {@damage 10d6} fire or necrotic damage (your choice) on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. The stone is destroyed upon use.

item.name: Runestone, Ithildin
entries: This small runestone seems suffused with hallowed energy.

As a bonus action, you can throw this stone toward one creature of your choice within 60 feet of you. You are considered proficient in this item when you throw it, and you may choose either dexterity, strength, intelligence or wisdom as the modifier used in the attack roll. On a hit, the stone deals radiant damage equal to {@damage 3d12} + your Dexterity, Strength, Intelligence or Wisdom modifier (your choice), and is destroyed upon impact.
Alternatively, you can use a bonus action to crush the stone in your palm, causing you to regain {@dice 3d12} hit points. The stone is then destroyed.

item.name: Lumenstone
entries: Lumenstone, otherwise known as Faronaar or rarely Lightstone, is a mineral which forms in clusters where magic runs rampant. It is used in enchanting, wherein it is processed to become a {@item Focal Stone|WorldOfLight}. It is otherwise used as a material in armor, as its magic-infused properties grant a slight resistance to magic.
Thus, any armor created with Lumenstone reduces damage taken by direct magic (such as {@spell fireball} and {@spell magic missile}) by 1.

item.name: Focal Stone
entries: The first step in creating a magical item is the initial plan for its function. During this step, a mage, while researching the spells, will also need to gather {@i Focal Stones}. These stones are gemstones, most of which are made from {@item Lumenstone|WorldOfLight}.

A Focal Stone can store up to 9 levels worth of spell slots, which the wielder can imbue into the Focal Stone by holding the stone in one hand and casting a spell. The spell then has no effect, other than to be stored in the Focal Stone. Once the Focal Stone has at least one level worth of spell slots, it can be used as a material component in the {@spell Transfer Enchantment} spell. While a Focal Stone can practically be used indefinitely, the more it is used, the more unstable the casting.
Moreover, the levels inside a Focal Stone can be used to recharge magical items, with one spell level being equal to one charge.
Finally, a Focal Stone can also be used as a spellcasting focus.

item.name: Pyremaul, The Shaping Hammer
entries: Forged from deep red iron, this massive hammer is set with a brilliant fire opal that shimmers with eternal flame.

entries.name: Dormant
entries: While Pyremaul is in a dormant state, you gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon. When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d6} fire damage.
Additionally, you can choose to have this weapon shed bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet (no action required).

entries.name: Awakened
entries: When Pyremaul reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:

items: The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
The extra fire damage dealt by the weapon increases to {@dice 2d6}.
As an action, you can slam Pyremaul into the ground to cast the {@spell burning hands} spell at 2nd level (save {@dc 15}). You can't use this property again until you finish a short or long rest.
Whenever you score a critical hit with this weapon, the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Exalted
entries: When Pyremaul reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:

items: The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
The extra fire damage dealt by the weapon increases to {@dice 3d6}.
When you cast {@spell burning hands} with the weapon, you do so at 3rd level and the save DC increases to 17.

When you score a critical hit with this weapon, the saving throw to avoid being knocked {@condition prone} increases to 17. You also roll an extra {@damage 3d6} fire damage when determining the extra damage for the critical hit.

When you kill a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can take {@damage 10d10} fire damage and immolate the creature's corpse. This damage can't be reduced in any way, and you die if this damage reduces you to 0 hit points. The immolated creature and everything it is wearing and carrying, except magic items, are reduced to a pile of ash. The creature can be restored to life only by means of a {@spell true resurrection} or a {@spell wish} spell. You can't use this property of the maul again until 7 days have passed.

item.name: Shield of The Resolute
entries: Forged from mithral by seven master dwarves, this large tower shield depicts the soul forge; the primordial forge where Dwarven souls go when they die, and where Angarrad first breathed life into the Dwarven race.

entries.name: Dormant
entries: While Shield of The Resolute is in a dormant state, you have resistance to force and fire damage, and have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned}, pertrified and knocked {@condition prone}.
Additionally, you gain a +1 bonus to Constitution saving throws.

entries.name: Awakened
entries: When the Shield of The Resolute reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:

items: The bonus to Constitution saving throws increases by 1, to a +2.
You become immune to being {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened} and being knocked {@condition prone}.
The bonus to AC increases by 1, to a +2.

entries.name: Exalted
entries: When Pyremaul reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:

items: The bonus to Constitution saving throws increases by 1, to a +3.
You gain a +1 bonus to AC for every two allies within 5 feet of you (up to a maximum of +3) while you wield this shield. This bonus is in addition to the shield's normal bonus to AC.
The bonus to AC increases by 1, to a +3.

item.name: Wraps of Dyamak
entries: Created and wielded by the ancient warrior-monk Dyamak, these thick strips of enchanted cloth are stained to appear dark crimson with blood of unknown origin. The current resting place of the wraps is unknown.

entries.name: Dormant
entries: When the Wraps of Dyamak are in a dormant state, you gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with your unarmed strike while wearing them.
In addition, when you finish a short or long rest, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your total number of ki points.

entries.name: Awakened
entries: When the Wraps of Dyamak reach an awakened state, they gain the following properties:

items: The bonus to attack and damage rolls with your unarmed strike increases to +2.

You can cast the {@spell misty step} spell from the wraps as a bonus action, vanishing in a cloud of crimson mist. This property of the wraps can't be used again until you finish a short or long rest, or until you score a critical hit with an unarmed strike against a hostile creature.

entries.name: Exalted
entries: When the Wraps of Dyamak reach an exalted state, they gain the following properties:

items: The bonus to attack and damage rolls with your unarmed strike increases to +3.

When you hit with an unarmed strike, you can choose to make the attack a ravenous strike. The target takes an extra {@damage 6d6} necrotic damage, and you regain hit points equal to the amount of necrotic damage dealt. This property of the wraps can't be used again until you finish a long rest, or until you score a critical hit with an unarmed strike against a hostile creature.

item.name: Plate of the Dawnmartyr
entries: Beautiful silver scrollwork and priceless cut rubies adorn this set of brass-and-gold armor.

entries.name: Dormant
entries: While the Plate of the Dawnmartyr is in a dormant state, you gain a +1 bonus to AC while wearing it. When a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to rebuke that creature, dealing it {@damage 1d6} fire damage.

entries.name: Awakened
entries: When the Plate of the Dawnmartyr reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:

items: The armor's bonus to AC increases to +2.
You are immune to the {@condition frightened} condition.
You have resistance to fire damage.
The fire damage you deal when you rebuke an attacker increases to {@dice 2d6}.

entries.name: Exalted
entries: When the Plate of the Dawnmartyr reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:

items: The armor's bonus to AC increases to +3.
When you rebuke an attacker, you can choose to deal either fire damage or radiant damage.

When you are reduced to 0 hit points, you can choose to have a blast of healing flame surround you. You regain 1 hit point and are lifted to your feet. Each enemy within 10 feet of you takes {@damage 2d6} fire damage or radiant damage (your choice). This property of the armor can't be used again until you finish a long rest.

item.name: Razor Bands of The Arch-Mage
entries: This steel orb is about 3 inches across, graven with lines and spirals. Created by the Arch-Mage Danoth during the Era of Magic, this steel-titanium alloyed ball resembles the iron bands of billaro greatly.

entries.name: Dormant
entries: While the Razor Bands of The Arch-Mage are in a dormant state, you can use an action to toss it into the air, having it orbit your head at a distance of {@dice 1d3} feet and confering benefits to you. A orb has an AC of 24, 10 hit points, and resistance to all damage. It is considered to be an object that is being worn while it orbits your head. Your Intelligence score increases by 2, to a maximum of 20, while the Razor Bands of The Arch-Mage orbit your head.

Additionally, while the Razor Bands of The Arch-Mage orbit your head, you can use an action to speak the command word and have the sphere leap at a Huge or smaller creature you can see within 60 feet of you. As the sphere moves through the air, it opens into a tangle of metal bands. Make a ranged attack roll with an attack bonus equal to your Dexterity or Intelligence modifier (your choice) plus your proficiency bonus. On a hit, the target is restrained until you take a bonus action to speak the command word again to release it. Doing so, or missing with the attack, causes the bands to contract and become a sphere once more, and will have the ball fly back to orbit your head. A {@condition restrained} creature can use an action to make a DC 20 Strength check to break free of the iron bands, upon which the bands go slack and the creature is freed.

entries.name: Awakened
entries: When the Razor Bands of The Arch-Mage reach an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:

items: Your Wisdom score increases by 2, to a maximum of 20, while the Razor Bands of The Arch-Mage orbit your head.
Any creature {@condition restrained} by the Razor Bands of The Arch-Mage takes 1d12 points of piercing damage on their turn, as jagged barbs jut out from the bands.

entries.name: Exalted
entries: When the Razor Bands of The Arch-Mage reach an exalted state, you gain the following benefit:

items: You regain 15 hit points at the end of each hour the Razor Bands of The Arch-Mage orbit your head, provided that you have at least 1 hit point.
You don't need to eat or drink while the Razor Bands of The Arch-Mage orbit your head.
The damage dealt to a {@condition restrained} creature increases to 2d12 piercing damage per turn.

item.name: Brand of The Blood Rage
item.reqAttune: by a barbarian, fighter, or paladin of evil alignment
entries: This sword was wielded by a votary of Hextor during the Crown Wars. Its red-gold edge is coated with countless runes seeped with blood. At its hilt is a ruby that emits a pale red mist.

entries.name: Dormant
entries: While the Brand of The Blood Rage is in a dormant state, you gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you hit a creature with an attack roll using this magic weapon, you can choose to mark it. Whenever you hit the marked creature afterwards, you deal an additional {@dice 1d6} necrotic damage.

entries.name: Awakened
entries: When the Brand of The Blood Rage reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:

items: The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2. Additionally, the damage against a marked creature increases to 2d6.
You can mark one additional creature, up to a maximum of 2.

entries.name: Exalted
entries: When the Brand of The Blood Rage reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefit:

items: The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3. Additionally, the damage against a marked creature increases to 3d6.
You can mark one additional creature, up to a maximum of 3.
Whenever you reduce a creature to 0 hit points using this weapon, you sap it's vitality, regaining hit points equal to the amount of damage dealt.

item.name: Cabal's Ruin
entries: Born from a lover's tryst between a votary of Ioun and a disciple of Kord, this cloak is made of heavy dark cloth trimmed with golden patterns, and occasionally shimmers with sparks of arcane energy.

entries.name: Dormant
entries: While Cabal's Ruin is in a dormant state, the cloak has 4 charges and it regains {@dice 1d4} expended charges daily at dawn. When you hit with an attack, you can expend any number of charges from the cloak, with the attack dealing an extra {@damage 1d6} lightning damage per charge expended. If your attack strikes multiple targets, you choose one target that takes this extra damage.

When you are targeted by an enemy's spell, you can use your reaction to absorb a portion of the spell's energy into the cloak. The spell affects you normally, but the cloak regains a number of charges equal to the level of the spell. This property can't be used again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Awakened
entries: When Cabal's Ruin reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects while wearing this cloak.
The cloak has 6 charges and it regains {@dice 1d4 + 2} expended charges daily at dawn.
When you use the cloak to absorb a spell, you gain resistance to one type of damage dealt by the spell (your choice). This resistance then lasts until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Exalted
entries: When Cabal's Ruin reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefit:

items: The cloak has 10 charges and it regains {@dice 1d6 + 4} expended charges daily at dawn.

item.name: Gemstone Tattoo
entries: Produced by a special needle, this magic tattoo contains a single {@filter 1st level spell|spells|level=1}, wrought on your skin by a magic needle. To use the tattoo, you must hold the needle against your skin and speak the command word. The needle turns into ink that becomes the tattoo, which appears on the skin in whatever design you like. Once the tattoo is there, you can cast its spell, requiring no material components. The tattoo glows faintly while you cast the spell and for the spell's duration. Once the spell ends, the tattoo vanishes from your skin.
The Ability modifier for this spell is +3; the Save DC is 13 and the attack bonus is +5.

item.name: Gardener's Tools
entries: This kit contains a variety of instruments such as a trowel, fertilizer, leather gloves, clippers, a watering can, a hoe, plant tags and a small set of matching clay pots used by gardeners to tend to the soil and plants. Proficiency with this kit lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make to identify or apply herbology. Also, proficiency with this kit is required to successfully nurture arcane plants and fungi.
additionalEntries: Proficiency with gardener's tools allows you to identify plants and fungi, and know how to grow each successfully.

additionalEntries.name: Perception and Survival

additionalEntries.name: Nature
entries: When you travel in the wild, your skill in herbalism makes it easier to identify plants and spot sources of food that others might overlook.
