variantrule.name: Playable Races of The World of Light
entries: The races of Ilúvë vary widely from continent to continent. Being a harsh world, many races have adapted to those hard environments, some even going as far as to completely embody that particular harsness in the form of slavery and warmongering. Whatever the case, below is given a list of all of the allowed playable races, sorted first by continent and secondly by rarity.

entries.name: Greywood, The Mainland
entries: Greywood is a continent of magic and malice. It's the starting continent for Of Might And Magic and Whispers of The Arcane, and it's the most varied in its races.

items: {@race Dwarf (Hill)|PHB|Hill Dwarves}, {@race Dwarf (Mountain)|PHB|Mountain Dwarves} and the ever-resented {@race Dwarf (Duergar)|MTF|Grey Dwarves} (otherwise known as Duergar).
Most Dwarves on Greywood dwell deep in the Ironpeak mountain range. There are four known Dwarven Clans on Greywood, which are as follows:

Clan Coppercoin - Mostly Hill Dwarves, especially adept at selling and procuring goods; expert merchants, most travel the globe and Greywood alike in search of {@deity Angaradd|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight|Angaradd's} blessing.

Clan Greyhand - Strictly Mountain Dwarves. The least-known Dwarvish Clan, said to have unearthed an ancient, esoteric secret deep beneath the earth. This clan is mostly shrouded in secrecy, as they are also said to keep the other Clans in check, without direct intervention.

Clan Cindersmith - A Clan of mostly Duergar and a small amount of Mountain Dwarves. This Clan is known to create many weapons for Clan Coppercoin to sell, and is also known as the Clan responsible for most "Good"-aligned Duegar. This Clan is also the only known clan to take in Gnomish Alchemists, Crafters and Artificers.

Clan Steelborn - A Clan of every type of Dwarf, most notably Mountain Dwarves. This Clan is most widespread near and in the Ironpeak Mountains, and one city can even be seen gleaming betwixt two mountains, Mynydd Laurë and Eredinior; the City of Dor-Durgarn.
{@race Elf (High)|PHB|High Elves}, {@race Elf (Wood)|PHB|Wood Elves} and {@race Drow|PHB|Dark Elves} (Otherwise known as Drow).

The Elves of Greywood are a tall, proud and more often than not, haughty race. The Elves were the first people of this land. They were the fey descendants who first named their homeland Syndar, centuries before humans gave it the name Greywood. The common origin of most elves lies within the wooded lands of what is now known as Sylingur, and many elves—Wood Elves and High Elves alike—still call the great forests their home.

Since the 3rd Era, relations between The Betrayers—the derogatory name for Dark Elves—and the other Elven subraces have slowly begun to improve, even so far that now, during the 4th Era, many Dark Elves no longer live underground, mingling with the other surface-dwellers. These Elves are known as Light or Ash Elves, and they have since branched off into two separate groups: Those whose ancestors followed Sehanine back to the light of the surface, and those who roam the ashen wastes of Nórdabad, prefering three of the Interloper Gods' grace, venerating them like the three-above-all.
{@race Goblin (Ash)|WorldOfLight|Ash Goblins}, {@race Goblin (Deep)|WorldOfLight|Deep Goblins} and {@race Goblin (Forest)|WorldOfLight|Forest Goblins}.

Whether they're wreaking havoc within the Shrouded Crags of Rana Mor, scurrying along the Wastes of Nordabȧd, or hidden in the Forest of Amoor-dânn and Aeldwen, Goblins are widespread and come in many different shapes and sizes. Similar to the {@race Dwarf|PHB|Dwarves}, many Goblins ally themselves with—or are born into—a clan.

{@race Goblin (Ash)|WorldOfLight|Ash Goblins}. Ash Goblins scurry about on the Ashen Plains, defiling Orcish shrines between the peaks of the Obsidian Ridge, and hauling along slaves and produce along the treacherous crags and desolate plains of the Wastes of Nordabȧd.

{@race Goblin (Deep)|WorldOfLight|Deep Goblins}. Deep Goblins chose to venture into the deepest pits of the Underdark, choosing to venerate Torog, purely out of fear. The many many years below ground has turned most of them blind, and this is directly seen in their armor; eyeless armor created from the chitin of the Rust Monsters they ride into battle with.

{@race Goblin (Forest)|WorldOfLight|Forest Goblins}. Forest Goblins are among the most varied, and even within the clans most Forest Goblins aren't without many differences. Forest Goblins are also seen as the most trustworthy, though this is very dependant on the clan-alliance of the goblin and even the forest one would find it in.

There are possibly thousands of goblin clans, situated along the Ironpeak Mountains, the Obsian Ridge, the Forest of Amoor-dânn and even the Fens and Bogs of the Ghostmere. The most prominent of which include the following:

{@b The Drar-Okaan}. Having been rendered blind to the caverns of the Underdark, the {@race Goblin (Deep)|WorldOfLight|Deep Goblins} of the Drar-Okaan tribe attempt to live by their wits—though seldom with much success. When a Drar-Okaan Goblin has the bright idea of trying to tame Rust Monster Larvae, at least a few others will be willing to follow that goblin into a nest—usually to predictably horrible results. But though the Drar-Okaan seem to have a never-ending supply of bad ideas, and a horrible ratio of bad ideas to good, the Drar-Okaan likewise seem to have a never-ending supply of Drar-Okaan. As such, by trial and error (and more error), these Goblins have stumbled across a great deal of knowledge useful for surviving the deep places of Ilúvë, and for dealing with the creatures that live there.

{@b The Ol'Rith'Narr Kinship}. Possibly the largest uneasy alliance between hordes of Goblins, the Ol'Rith'Narr Kinship is a large tribe consisting of both Warmongering, Bloodthirsty {@race Goblin (Ash)|WorldOfLight|Ash Goblins}, {@race Orc|PHB|Orcs} and a strange mix of Chromatic (usually black-scaled) {@race Dragonborn|WorldOfLight|Dragonborn} occupying most of the Wastes of Nordabȧd. Throughout the ranks of the Ol'Rith'Narr, action and strength are valued above diplomacy, and its leaders earn respect by the blade, wasting no time with politics. The brutality of the Ol'Rith'Narr's champions is focused, giving a voice to those who fight for survival. It is also widely known that the Ol'Rith'Narr are a major chess piece in the Arcaborian Empire's slipping grip of their dominion over the Wastes, going so far as that the Empire now no longer considers Nordabád to be under their rule.

{@b The Redclaw Clan}. The most lighthearted of the three prominent clans, the Redclaw Clan is home to many {@race Goblin (Forest)|WorldOfLight|Forest Goblins}, and have a special, magical facepaint that shows other members of the Redclaw Clan their allegiance. Members of the Redclaw clan guard places of Civilization against the lesser evils, and see themselves as neutral (though chaotic at times) forces to stop the lesser evils from encroaching into the safe walls of cities like The Old City and Myth Ancalen. In addition, the Redclaw Clan is most well-known for Smunsen's Soup Emporium; a place hidden—albeit not very well—within the Forests that surround the Old City.
{@race Halfling (Lightfoot)|PHB|Lightfoot Halflings} and {@race Halfling (Stout)|PHB|Stout Halflings}.

Known as the children of The Changebringers, many Halflings are proud of their heritage, though each one is more humble than the next. Widespread as they are, most value community and are concerned with themselves and their immediate surroundings. Many prefer the simple life, so most live their lives in small hamlets, and many make their home in The Empire, prefering it's tranquility and, most importantly, it's stability.

{@race Half-Elf|PHB|Half-Elves}. After the fledgling races found themselves on the world of Ilúvë, soon they began intermingling, with the ever-so-adventrous elves to try many different pairings, creating the Half-Elves. Most Half-Elves on Greywood are the direct result of Human and High-Elven or Wood-Elven pairings, Though pairings of elves with other races also exist, albeit increasingly rare.

{@race Human|PHB|Humans}. Humans of the Vilt are far and between, and are just as ruthless as their Orc and Half-Orc brethren. Originally tribes hailing from Greywood, most humans that migrated to The Vilt sought to worship the gods of pride and conquest, believing in the more barbaric way of life. When playing a human from the Vilt, players can choose between both the {@race Human|PHB} and {@race Human (Variant)|PHB|Variant Human} subraces as well as the {@race Human (Mark of Handling)|ERLW} and {@race Human (Keldon)|PSD} subraces.

entries: Flanking, in most D&D games, happens when a creature and at least one of its allies are adjacent to an enemy and on opposite sides or corners of the enemy's space. {@i Flanking+}, as I'd like to call it, expands on this rule, editing its effects.

The regular {@variantrule flanking} rules still apply, with one major difference. Instead of gaining advantage, the flanking creature instead gains a +2 bonus to hit against flanked creature. This means that flanking can also stack with other effects, such as effects that give advantage: not making it as strong as it is in the base game.

In addition to this change, creatures that have multiple eyes (such as a beholder), can see from multiple directions or otherwise have a special sense—such as {@sense blindsight} or {@sense truesight}—cannot be flanked.
Exploding Crits, or {@i Crit+}, is a simply variant rule that rewards players' good rolls with a bit of extra crunch.

Whenever a player (or the DM, for that matter) rolls a natural 20 on an attack roll, they'd roll the damage dice twice, like normal. However, using this rule, if any of their dice show the highest possible face (i.e. a "6" on the d6), the die "explodes". Once it does, the die is rolled again, and the rolls are summed.
This does open up the possibility of multiple explosions, as, for example, the d4 is very prone to explosions. It's not unthinkable to get an explosion sequence like 4 + 4 + 3 after a few tries.
Whatever the case, the dice explodes until it no longer can (so if anything except it's highest face is rolled after it's exploded).

entries.name: Age
entries: Goblins reach adulthood at age 8 and live up to 60 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Ash goblins are typically lawful evil, as ride in packs on their fearsome worgs, prefering to hunt together. A few goblins might tend toward good or neutrality, but only rarely.

entries.name: Size
entries: Ash goblins are the largest and strongest of the goblin subraces; they are anywhere between 4 and just under 5 feet tall and weigh between 80 and 120 pounds. If you embody the bulkier sides of the Ash Goblins, your size is Medium, and if you embody the smaller grunts of the Ash Goblins, your size is Small.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Nimble Escape
entries: You can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide action} as a bonus action on each of your turns.

entries.name: Fury of the Small
entries: When you damage a creature with an attack or a spell and the creature's size is larger than yours, you can cause the attack or spell to deal extra damage to the creature. The extra damage equals your level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Worg Rider
entries: Ash goblins have an amicable relationship with worgs, whom they ride into battle. You have proficiency in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Goblin.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Deep goblins are typically neutral evil, as they care only for their own needs. A few goblins might tend toward good or neutrality, but only rarely.

entries.name: Size
entries: Deep goblins are between 3 and 4 feet tall and weigh between 40 and 80 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Blindsight
entries: Deep goblins thrive in the many caves and caverns beneath the world, though years and years in the darkness has rendered them blind. Thus, you have Blindsense out to a range of 30 feet. You are blind beyond this radius.

entries.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: You have disadvantage on attack rolls and on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight when you, the target of your attack, or whatever you are trying to perceive is in direct sunlight.

entries.name: Fury of the Small
entries: When you damage a creature with an attack or a spell and the creature's size is larger than yours, you can cause the attack or spell to deal extra damage to the creature. The extra damage equals your level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Naturally Stealthy
entries: You can attempt to hide even when you are obscured only by a creature that is at least one size larger than you.

entries.name: Stoneskin
entries: You can move across difficult terrain made of earth or stone without expending extra movement.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Goblin.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Forest goblins are typically neutral or neutral good, though some mischievous forest goblins are chaotic neutral.

entries.name: Size
entries: Forest goblins are smaller than most Ash Goblins, though some tribes prefer lanky and tall offspring. Your size is Small or Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Nimble Escape
entries: You can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide action} as a bonus action on each of your turns.

entries.name: Fury of the Small
entries: When you damage a creature with an attack or a spell and the creature's size is larger than yours, you can cause the attack or spell to deal extra damage to the creature. The extra damage equals your level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Speak with Small Beasts
entries: Through sounds and gestures, you can communicate simple ideas with Small or smaller beasts. Forest goblins love animals and often keep squirrels, badgers, rabbits, moles, woodpeckers, and other creatures as beloved pets.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Goblin.

entries.name: Age
entries: Kobolds reach adulthood at age 6 and can live up to 120 years but rarely do so.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Kobolds are fundamentally selfish, making them evil, but their reliance on the strength of their group makes them trend toward law.

entries.name: Size
entries: Kobolds are between 2 and 3 feet tall and weigh between 25 and 35 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Grovel, Cower, and Beg
entries: As an action on your turn, you can cower pathetically to distract nearby foes. Until the end of your next turn, your allies gain advantage on attack rolls against enemies within 10 feet of you that you can see. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Pack Tactics
entries: You have advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: You have disadvantage on attack rolls and on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight when you, the target of your attack, or whatever you are trying to perceive is in direct sunlight.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Draconic.

entries.name: Age
entries: Loxodons physically mature at the same rate as humans, but they live about 450 years. They highly value the weight of wisdom and experience and are considered young until they reach the age of 60.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most loxodons are lawful, believing in the value of a peaceful, ordered life. They also tend toward good.

entries.name: Size
entries: Loxodons stand between 7 and 8 feet tall. Their massive bodies weigh between 300 and 400 pounds. Your size is Large.

entries.name: Loxodon Serenity
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: You have thick, leathery skin. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC is 12 + your Constitution modifier. You can use your natural armor to determine your AC if the armor you wear would leave you with a lower AC. A shield's benefits apply as normal while you use your natural armor.

entries.name: Tip: AC Calculations Don't Stack
entries: When the game gives you more than one way to calculate your Armor Class, you can use only one of them. You choose the one to use. For example, if you have the loxodon's Natural Armor trait and the monk's Unarmored Defense feature, you don't mix them together. Instead, you choose which one determines your AC.

entries.name: Trunk
entries: You can grasp things with your trunk, and you can use it as a snorkel. It has a reach of 5 feet, and it can lift a number of pounds equal to five times your Strength score. You can use it to do the following simple tasks: lift, drop, hold, push, or pull an object or a creature; open or close a door or a container; grapple someone; or make an unarmed strike. Your DM might allow other simple tasks to be added to that list of options.
Your trunk can't wield weapons or shields or do anything that requires manual precision, such as using tools or magic items or performing the somatic components of a spell.

entries.name: Keen Smell
entries: Thanks to your sensitive trunk, you have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}), Wisdom ({@skill Survival}), and Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks that involve smell.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Loxodon.

entries.name: Age
entries: Shardminds were created fully mature, and do not physically age.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Shardminds are fragments of pure thought given life and substance. They are logical, emotionally distant, and naive to the ways of society in the world. The Shardmind race has spent thousands of years tending gardens of living crystal. Due to this, they are familiar with order and routine and have a strong lawful bent. They are scarcely evil and are usually good or neutral.

entries.name: Size
entries: Shardminds are crystalline creatures consisting of hundreds of small shards of translucent green, white, red, or amber crystal assembled into humanoid form and animated by a force of pure psionic energy. Shardminds range from small crystalline buds, mere 3 feet in height, to large geode-like behemoths, well over 7 feet. Their hard crystalline body makes them much heavier than humans, at around 180 to 230 pounds. Your size is Small, Medium or Large.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to chaotic thunder and dazzling arrays of colour of the Astral Plane, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. Your darkvision is special though, as you can't discern color in darkness, and everything is in a pinkish hue.

entries.name: Crystalline Mind
entries: You can communicate mentally with another creature that knows the same language you do within a 60-foot radius. This creature needs to share a language with you, and unless they have telepathy themselves they can only receive and respond but can't initiate or terminate a telepathic conversation. You must be conscious to use this trait and while you can telepathically communicate with multiple creatures at once, conversing telepathically with multiple creatures simultaneously is just as difficult as listening to multiple people speak. In addition, you have resistance to psychic damage.

entries.name: Crystalline Body
entries: Even though you were constructed, you are a living creature. You are immune to diseases. You do not need to eat or breathe, but you can ingest food and drink if you wish.

entries.name: Arcane Psionics
entries: Because you came from The Living Gate, arcane energy courses through your body. You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put you to sleep.

In addition, you know the {@spell mage hand} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell detect magic spell} once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can cast the {@spell detect thoughts} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Primordial, but can speak only using your Crystalline Mind feature. Additionally, you understand Shardspeak, a strange language made up of deep, resonating humming only communicated by telepaths, and very few beings other than the Shardminds themselves know it. It uses the Primordial script.

entries.name: Age
entries: As Wilden age, their bodies move through the seasons. Young Wilden are like trees in spring, filled with life and vigor—their bodies a green hue. In the Summer phase, a Wilden's body is brown or tan, while the cloak of leaves remain vibrant green. Wilden in the autumn phase undergo a profound change, their skin darkening as their leaves turn color to reds, yellows, and oranges. Finally, the winter phase heralds the end of a Wilden's life, as the body grows thinner and the Wilden's leaves wither and fall. A typical Wilden lives more than a century; just over 100 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: As a protector of nature, Wilden tend to lean towards neutral. Wilden also tend to be good in nature, due to their relative naivety and love of the wild.

entries.name: Size
entries: Wilden range from just under 5 feet to just over 6 feet. Their plant-like body makes them lighter than humans, at around 100 to 140 pounds. Your size is medium.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: Your are a Fey, which means you count as Fey for the purposes of determining spells and effects that affect Fey.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to twilit forests of the Feywild, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Sylvan.

entries.name: Nature's Aspect
entries: {@i Choose your Wilden's Aspect: Ancients, Destroyer or Hunter. When finishing a long rest, any Wilden can change their Aspect. See the "Info" tab for more information.}

entries.name: Aspect of The Ancients
items: While embodying the Aspect of the Ancients, you gain the following benefits:

{@b Fey Magic}. You know the {@spell Druidcraft} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Spike Growth} spell as a 2nd-level spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can cast the {@spell Misty Step} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.
{@b Knowledge of The Ancients}. You gain proficiency with the {@item Quarterstaff|PHB}, {@item Scimitar|PHB}, {@item Light Crossbow|PHB}, and {@item Longbow|PHB}.

{@b Voyage of The Ancients}. When you reach 3rd level, you gain the power of this Aspect. Immediately after you hit a creature, you can teleport up to 15 feet away. This movement does not provoke an attack of opportunity. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Aspect of the Destroyer
items: While embodying the Aspect of the Destroyer, you gain the following benefits:
{@b Savage Attacks}. When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon’s damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.
{@b Destroyer Weapon Honing}. You gain proficiency with the {@item Battleaxe|PHB}, {@item Quarterstaff|PHB}, {@item Shortbow|PHB}, and {@item Longbow|PHB}.

{@b Wrath of the Destroyer}. When you reach 3rd level, you gain the power of this Aspect. Whenever a creature within 5 feet of you makes an attack roll against you, you can use your reaction to make one attack against that creature. If your attack hits, the enemy must succeed on a constitution saving throw (DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier) or be {@condition stunned} until the end of your next turn. Once you hit with this attack you cannot use this ability again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Aspect of the Hunter
items: While embodying the Aspect of the Hunter, you gain the following benefits:

{@b Language of The Tree-jumper}. You can communicate with beasts and plants. You also have advantage on Charisma checks to influence them. These creatures can understand the meaning of your words, even though you cannot understand them in return.
{@b Hunter Martial Gifts}. You gain proficiency with the {@item Spear|PHB}, {@item Scimitar|PHB}, {@item Shortbow|PHB}, and {@item Longbow|PHB}.

{@b Pursuit of the Hunter}. Whenever a creature provokes an attack of opportunity from you, if you hit that creature, you can choose to learn the following traits about the enemy: Its Armor Class, its maximum hit points, one of its resistances and one of its saving throw bonuses. Once you use this ability, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Unending Breath
entries: You can hold your breath indefinitely while you're not {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Mingle with the Wind
entries: You can cast the {@spell levitate} spell once with this trait, requiring no material components, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Fey Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell Druidcraft} cantrip. At 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Charm Person} spell once per day at 2nd level, and at 5th level, you can cast the {@spell Pass without Trace} spell once per day. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common, Infernal and Sylvan.

entries.name: One with Stone
entries: Climbing stone surfaces doesn't cost you extra movement

entries.name: Binding Clay
entries: You can cast the {@spell Maximilian's Earthen Grasp|XGE} spell once with this trait, requiring no material components, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Cold Resistance
entries: You have resistance to cold damage.

entries.name: Frost Walk
entries: You can move across difficult terrain created by ice or snow without expending extra movement. While crossing bodies of water, you can freeze a thin layer of water below the soles of your feet, and walk across the surface of water as if on solid ground. The thin ice sheets beneath your soles melt as soon as you lift your feet, and you cannot be carrying anything heavier than your carrying capacity.

entries.name: Command Over Ice
entries: You know the {@spell frostbite} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell snilloc's snowball swarm|XGE} spell once with this trait as a 1st-level spell, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Fire Resistance
entries: You have resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Molten Shell
entries: After you finish a long rest, you gain a layer of protective rock, providing temporary hit points equal to twice your Constitution modifier. When an enemy deals damage to the layer with a melee attack, they take {@dice 1d6} fire damage. If you choose to gain temporary hit points from any other source, thsi feature is immediately lost. The layer cannot be replenished by any means, except by taking a long rest.

entries.name: Searing Combustion
entries: You know the {@spell fire bolt} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell pyrotechnics|XGE} spell once with this trait as a 1st-level spell, and you regain the ability to cast it this way when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

spell.name: Accelerated Deceleration

m.text: a small stone statuette of a whale

entries: This spell is used by apprentice chronurgists to hone their time-manipulating powers. You can create one of the following magical effects within range:

items: You can create a small magical wonder, such as growing a flower in a spot where flowers don't grow, causing small snowflakes to fall to the ground around you, or even make a summer breeze pass under a creatures feet. The extent of these effects are up to you, at the DM's discretion.
You can spoil or freshen one piece of food no larger than 1 cubic foot you can see within range. This doesn't work on food which has been spoiled for over a week.

You can suspend one object weighing no more than 10 lbs up to 10 feet into the air. Any pressure or weight put on it will immediately make it fall back down to the ground. While it is suspended in this way, it slightly oscillates and rotates in place, giving off a faint, celestial hum.
You can immediately learn the precise time of day to the nearest minute, including the current hour, day, month, and year.

You can accelerate or decelerate time centered on a point within range. Anything within 1 cubic foot of the point you chose is affected by this effect. Examples of this effect include bringing a cauldron of water to a boil in seconds or causing a clock to speed up or down to show to wrong time. The extent of these effects are up to you, at the DM's discretion.
You can turn back time on a small fire, such as a candle, torch or small campfire, lighting or snuffing it out instantly.

entries: If you cast this spell multiple times, you can have up to three of its non-instantaneous effects active at a time, and you can dismiss such an effect as an action.

spell.name: Alinaar's Amazing Altering

m.text: A small pile of ash, a diamond worth at least 200 gp and a broken horn

entries: This spell transforms you or a creature you touch into a new form. The transformation lasts for the duration, or until you drop to 0 hit points or die. The new form can be any beast, dragon, elemental, giant, monstrosity, ooze, or plant whose challenge rating is equal to or less than your current level. Your game statistics, including mental ability scores, are replaced by the statistics of the chosen creature. You retain your alignment and personality.

You assume the hit points of your new form. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before you transformed. If you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. As long as the excess damage doesn't reduce your normal form to 0 hit points, you aren't knocked unconscious. You are limited in the actions you can perform by nature of your new form, and you can't speak, cast spells, or take any other action that requires hands or speech unless your new form is naturally capable of doing so.

If the new form doesn't wield equipment then your gear melds into the new form. You can't activate, use wield, or otherwise benefit from any of your equipment. If the new form is one that normally wields equipment then your gear transforms into the new form's standard equipment, as determined by the DM.

spell.name: Ana's Aiding Aura
entries: Healing power radiates from you in an aura with a 5-foot radius, soothing pain in friendly creatures. Until the spell ends, the aura moves with you, centered on you. While in the aura, all allies in the aura (including you) heal {@dice 1d8} + your spellcasting modifier whenever they start their turn in the aura or move through it's space on their turn.

spell.name: Murgaxor's Crimson Lash
entries: As part of casting this spell, you must expend a hit die or the spell automatically fails. If you do, a writhing lash of coagulated blood springs from your hand.

This magic weapon lasts until the spell ends. It counts as a simple weapon with which you are proficient, and it has the light, finesse, and reach properties. You can choose to add your spellcasting modifier, instead of your Strength or Dexterity modifier, to attack and damage rolls with this weapon. Its damage die is equivalent to the hit die expended casting this spell, and the damage dealt is necrotic. Each time a creature takes damage from this magic weapon, its maximum hit points are reduced by an amount equal to the damage it took.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd or 4th level, when you take the {@action Attack} action, you can make two weapon attacks, provided both are with this magic weapon. When you use a spell slot of 5th level or higher, when you take the {@action Attack} action you make three weapon attacks, provided all are with this magic weapon.

spell.name: Duncan's Brand of Weakness

m.text: A small mark on your body, such as a tattoo or an {@feat abberant dragonmark|ERLW}

entries: You temporarily expose the weak points of an enemy. The targeted creature becomes vulnerable to Bludgeoning, Piercing or Slashing damage (your choice). If the target is already vulnerable to the chosen damage, this spell has no effect. This effect lasts for 3 turns, or until the target takes damage.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for for every two slot levels above 1st. The creatures must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them, and neither can be outside of the original casting range.

spell.name: Duncan's Rideable Hog

m.text: a small piece of blue gemstone and a small piece of rectangular leather

entries: Perhaps a misnomer, this spell was created by the cleric Duncan Ginning in an attempt to tame his newfound dire boar, Bartholomew.

You summon a translucent blue saddle, sized for a Small, Medium, or Large mount of your choice, within range. The saddle appears in an unoccupied space adjacent to the mount, and can be donned by you as a bonus action.

The saddle is made of shimmering, translucent blue energy and provides no physical substance or weight, but functions as a normal saddle in all other ways. The mount gains the benefits of the saddle, including increased stability and comfort while being ridden, and the rider gains advantage on any checks or saves made to maintain control of the mount.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the duration of the spell increases by 1 hour for each slot level above 1st. Additionally, you can summon a saddle one size larger for each 2nd level spell slot or higher.

spell.name: Duraan's Crystalline Receptacle

m.text: a gem, crystal or piece of {@item Lumenstone|WorldOfLight} worth at least 200gp

entries: You take a small gem, crystal or piece of Lumenstone, and trace transmutative sigils along it's surface, pointing it at one loose object within range. The object is then pulled into the receptacle, and is stored there indefinitely, in stasis. Alternatively, you can store multiple items into the receptacle by encircling the items using magic chalk worth at least 5 gp. The contents do not age, weather, or rot. The receptacle can hold up to 500lbs of material.

To release the contents, you can use an action to speak a single, chosen word and release the gem's contents onto the ground. A dispel magic used on the receptacle will shatter it, spilling the contents on the ground in the nearest unoccupied space within 5 feet of you.

spell.name: Fortune's Favor

m.text: a white pearl worth at least 100 gp

entries: You impart latent luck to yourself or one willing creature you can see within range. When the chosen creature makes an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw before the spell ends, it can dismiss this spell on itself to roll an additional {@dice d20} and choose which of the {@dice d20}s to use. Alternatively, when an attack roll is made against the chosen creature, it can dismiss this spell on itself to roll a {@dice d20} and choose which of the {@dice d20}s to use, the one it rolled or the one the attacker rolled.
If the original {@dice d20} roll has advantage or disadvantage, the creature rolls the additional {@dice d20} after advantage or disadvantage has been applied to the original roll.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Gallen's Healing Spirit
entries: You call forth a nature spirit to soothe the wounded. The intangible spirit appears in a space that is a 5-foot cube you can see within range. The spirit looks like a transparent beast or fey (your choice).

Until the spell ends, whenever you or a creature you can see moves into the spirit's space for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, you can cause the spirit to restore {@dice 1d6} hit points to that creature (no action required). The spirit can't heal constructs or undead.
As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the spirit up to 30 feet to a space you can see.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the healing increases by {@scaledice 1d6|3-9|1d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Hallaster's Tower

components.m: a fragment of stone, wood, or other building material

entries: You conjure a two-story tower made of stone, wood, or similar suitably sturdy materials. The tower can be round or square in shape. Each level of the tower is 10 feet tall and has an area of up to 100 square feet. Access between levels consists of a simple ladder and hatch. Each level takes one of the following forms, chosen by you when you cast the spell:

items: A bedroom with a bed, chairs, chest, and magical fireplace
A study with desks, books, bookshelves, parchments, ink, and ink pens
A dining space with a table, chairs, magical fireplace, containers, and cooking utensils
A lounge with couches, armchairs, side tables and footstools
A washroom with toilets, washtubs, a magical brazier, and sauna benches
An observatory with a telescope and maps of the night sky
An unfurnished, empty room

entries: The interior of the tower is warm and dry, regardless of conditions outside. Any equipment or furnishings conjured with the tower dissipate into smoke if removed from it. At the end of the spell's duration, all creatures and objects within the tower that were not created by the spell appear safely outside on the ground, and all traces of the tower and its furnishings disappear.

You can cast this spell again while it is active to maintain the tower's existence for another 24 hours. You can create a permanent tower by casting this spell in the same location and with the same configuration every day for one year.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the tower can have one additional story for each slot level beyond 3rd.

spell.name: Magefire
entries: You instantly cause a small harmless colored flame to appear in an unoccupied space you can see within range. The effect looks like a regular flame, but it creates no heat and doesn't use oxygen. Magefire can be covered or hidden but not smothered or quenched. The flames' color and light can be colored as you like, and the flame gives off dim light in a 5-foot radius.
The duration of this spell is one day or until dispelled. In addition, you can have multiple flames active at the same time, up to a maximum of 3.

The amount of flames you can have active at once, as well as the spell's duration, increases when you reach certain levels. At 5th level, the duration increases by one day (for a total of 2 days), and the amount of flames you can have active increase to 5. Both of these numbers increase by 2 at 11th level (5 days & 8 flames), and at 17th level the duration increases to 1 week and the amount of flames you can have active at once becomes unlimited.

spell.name: Matthias' Protective Dome
entries: You create a magical 60-foot-radius dome of force energy around you that moves with you. No creature, object, spell, gaze, or breath weapon can enter the dome unless you allow it.

Any creature hostile to you inside the dome when you cast this spell must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, taking {@dice 12d8} force damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. The creature must also succeed on a Strength saving throw, or, unless it is willing, be jettisoned outside the dome to the nearest unnocupied space next to the dome. If a creature succeeds on the strength saving throw, it takes {@dice 5d6} force damage each round while in still in the dome.
The dome can be destroyed with enough effort. The dome has 100 hit points and is resistant to fire and cold damage, and is immune to poison damage. An antimagic field has no effect on the dome.

spell.name: Qo's Thunderous Roar
entries: You let out a magically amplified dragon-like roar. Each creature in a 10-foot cube originating from you must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@dice 3d12} thunder damage and is pushed 15 feet away from you and knocked {@condition prone}. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed or knocked {@condition prone}.

In addition, unsecured objects that are completely within the area of effect are automatically pushed 15 feet away from you by the spell's effect, and the spell emits a draconic boom audible out to 500 feet.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledamage 1d8|3,5,7,9|1d8} for every two slot levels above 3rd.

spell.name: Radial Dispel
entries: A burst of glowing dust emanates from you in all directions in a 15-foot-radius. Any magical effect or spell of 4th level or lower within that radius end. For each spell within this radius that is of 5th level or higher, make an ability check using your spellcasting ability. The DC equals 10 + the spell's level. For each successful check, the individual spells also end.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, you automatically end the effects of spells or magical effects if the spell's level is equal to or less than the level of the spell slot you used.

spell.name: Rhoderihck's Speedy Courier

m.text: 25 gp, or mineral goods of equivalent value, which the spell consumes

entries: You summon a Small fire elemental to a spot within range. The fire elemental is formless, nearly transparent, immune to all damage, and cannot interact with other creatures or objects. It carries an open, empty chest whose interior dimensions are 3 feet on each side. While the spell lasts, you can deposit as many items inside the chest as will fit. You can then name a living creature you have met and seen at least once before, or any creature for which you possess a body part, lock of hair, clipping from a nail, or similar portion of the creature's body.

As soon as the lid of the chest is closed, the elemental and the chest disappear, then reappear adjacent to the target creature. If the target creature is on another plane, or if it is proofed against magical detection or location, the contents of the chest reappear on the ground at your feet.

The target creature is made aware of the chest's contents before it chooses whether or not to open it, and knows how much of the spell's duration remains in which it can retrieve them. No other creature can open the chest and retrieve its contents. When the spell expires or when all the contents of the chest have been removed, the elemental and the chest disappear. The elemental also disappears if the target creature orders it to return the items to you. When the elemental disappears, any items not taken from the chest reappear on the ground at your feet.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using an 8th-level spell slot, you can send the chest to a creature on a different plane of existence from you.

spell.name: Rhoderihck's Web of Fire

m.text: a knitting resembling a fireball or string coated in phosphorus

entries: Striking both palms down upon the ground, a web of flame crackles out around you and five streaks of fire rapidly snake along the ground toward up to five enemies that you can see within range, leaping towards their target and exploding into a column of flame upon reaching them. Each target must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@dice 8d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Alternatively, all five streaks of fire can instead converge toward a single target, dealing {@dice 12d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The fire can travel over obstacles up to 5 feet high, and ignites flammable objects along its path that aren't being worn or carried.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledice 8d6|4-9|1d6} (8d6) or {@scaledice 12d6|4-9|1d6} (12d6) for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Robin's Resonant Echo
entries: You tap into unused branching timelines to create an echo copy of yourself that has the ability to cast one spell that you have prepared before vanishing. The spell level of the spell cast by the echo must be lower than the level of the spell slot used to cast the echo. If the echo casts a spell that requires concentration, you maintain concentration on that spell when the echo disappears. If you were already concentrating on a spell, choose which spell you will maintain concentration on, and which spell will dissapate.

The echo has hit points equal to half your hit point maximum (rounded up), and you can use a bonus action on each of your turns to move the echo up to 30 feet in any direction. The echo cannot go through enemies nor can it pass through walls.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, another echo is created for each slot above 4th. However, any duplicate other than the first cannot cast spells. You can however, when using a bonus action to move a duplicate, move all of the duplicates at once, each in a separate direction.

spell.name: Robin's Resourceful Rescue

time.condition: which you take when an ally you can see within 60 feet of you gets hit by an attack or after it is subject to a dexterity saving throw

m.text: a small wooden statuette of a Balor

entries: Whenever you cast this spell, you instantly teleport up to 60 feet to the triggering target. Once the attack or save is resolved, if the creature is willing, you can choose to teleport again, up to 60 feet to any unoccupied space you can see, taking them with you.
When you teleport for the final time, the target reappears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you, or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the amount of willing creatures you can take with you increases by 1 for every slot level above 3rd. Whenever you teleport to another creature, the target must be within 30 feet of each other.
If you take multiple creatures, they all reappear in unoccupied spaces within 5 feet of you or in the nearest unoccupied space if all those spaces are occupied.

spell.name: Ruskar's Annihilate
entries: This spell unleashes magic that rips the souls from living creatures you can see within range.

Each creature in a 30-foot radius sphere centered on a point you choose within range must succeed on a Charisma saving throw, taking {@dice 15d12 + 30} necrotic damage, or half as much on a successful one.

If a creature fails its saving throw and is reduced to 0 hit points by this spell, it instantly dies, and it's soul is completely torn asunder, and it can't be ressurected, not even by means of a {@spell wish} spell.

spell.name: Spellward
entries: You trace a warding sigil in the air, creating a barrier of magical force that can absorb some damage before dissapating. This magical ward gives you total cover to incoming attacks, and has 30 hit points. While holding this ward, you cannot cast another spell, and must use your movement on every subsequent round to keep it up.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the ward gains an addition 10 hit points for each slot level above 2nd. In addition, any creature of your choice within 5 feet of you also becomes warded. For every slot level above 2nd, you can choose one additional creature within 5 feet of you to ward.

spell.name: Stormgard's Sojourn of Secrecy

components.m: A small wad of cotton or wool

entries: You create a small, invisible illusory pocket space, which muffles all sound from the outside going in, as well as the inside going out. For the duration, no sound can pass through a 20-foot square centered on a point you choose within range. Any creature or object entirely inside the sphere is {@condition deafened} to everything outside of the sphere while entirely inside it. Any creature outside of the spell's range cannot hear what is going on inside of the area. Casting inside the sphere is still possible, but only audible to those inside of the sphere as well.
This spell does not block other spells going in or out.

spell.name: Stormgard's Shocking Sword

m.text: a melee weapon worth at least 1 sp

entries: You brandish the weapon used in the spell's casting and make a melee attack with it against one creature within 5 feet of you. On a hit, the target suffers the weapon attack's normal effects, and must succeed a Constitution saving throw or become {@condition restrained} for 1 minute and take {@damage 1d4} lightning damage, as white-blue electricity crackles through it's body, leaving it in a state of minor paralysis as its muscles spasm uncontrollably. Each round on its turn, a {@condition restrained} creature can use an action to attempt to repeat the Constitution saving throw to stop being {@condition restrained}.

This spell's damage increases when you reach certain levels. At 5th level, the melee attack deals an extra {@damage 1d8} lightning damage to the target on a hit instead. This damage increases by {@damage 1d8} at 11th level ({@damage 2d8}) and again at 17th level ({@damage 3d8}).

spell.name: Thunder Spell
entries: You crackle lightning between your fingers and pull down, causing a lightning bolt to strike at a creature or object within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d10} lightning damage. A flammable object hit by this spell ignites if it isn't being worn or carried.
This spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d10} when you reach 5th level ({@damage 2d10}), 11th level ({@damage 3d10}), and 17th level ({@damage 4d10}).

races.name: Half-Elf (Variant; Moon Elf or Sun Elf Descent)

spell.name: Transfer Enchantment

time.condition: per rarity level of the transferring item

components.m: The magical items used in the transferring and an enchanted Lumenstone worth at least 100gp, the enchantment of which is consumed

entries: You transfer the magical qualities (properties, powers, and attack and/or bonus) of an enchanted item into another object. The receiving item must occupy the same magic item slot and be the same type as the original item. The enchantment to be moved must be valid for the receiving item, so that you cannot transfer ranged weapon properties to melee weapons, cloth-only armor properties to chainmail, and so on.

You can transfer an enchantment to an item that already contains an enchantment, but the receiving item must be of a rarity lower than the transferring item, and the receiving item’s previous magic is lost. Additionally, if you cast this spell in an attempt to transfer an Artifact or Vestiges' power, it simply fails.

spell.name: Trickster's Gyves
entries: Heavy immovable translucent chains of force-like energy, firmly tied to the body, hold the target in place. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or take {@dice 4d6} force damage and become {@condition restrained} and knocked {@condition prone} until the spell ends, and it can't move or be moved by any means until then. If an airborne creature is affected by this spell, it is held aloft in the air, and not affected by the {@condition prone} condition. If it succeeds, it takes half damage and isn't {@condition restrained} and knocked {@condition prone}.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledice 4d6|3-9|1d6} for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Wristpocket
entries: You flick your wrist with a flourish, causing a single object in your hand to vanish.

The object, which only you can be holding and weighs no more than 5 pounds, is actually transported and stored within a small extradimensional space. The object remains there indefinitely until this cantrip is cast again, until you fall unconscious or die, upon which it is immediately transported back into your grasp, or in your space at your feet if you fall unconscious or die. You cannot store an object while one already occupies the extradimensional pocket.

spell.name: Zegarowyzs' Hastened Rest

m.text: a candle lit when you cast this spell and blown out when you finish your rest

entries: In need for a quicker rest, you ritualistically allow yourself and others to bear a student's dream; sleep longer, faster.

You and up to 4 willing creatures within range experience time dilation. Whenever you cast this spell, while taking a long or short rest, time passes twice as long in your minds, letting you take a rest by spending only half of the required time resting. This spell can be used to take both a short or long rest quicker.

{@note If you cast this spell before a long  or short rest, you finish the rest after only 4 hours (or 30 minutes, in the case of a short rest). You otherwise obey all the rules for a long or short rest; only the duration is changed. Thus, creatures with the Trance feature only require 2 hours of sleep instead of 4.}

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the number of creatures you can affect increase by 1 for every spell slot above 4th.

subclass.name: Way of the Moon Soul
subclassFeatures: Way of The Moon Soul|Monk||Moon Soul|WorldOfLight|3

subclass.name: Oath of the Open Sea
subclassFeatures: Oath of the Open Sea|Paladin||Open Sea|WorldOfLight|3

subclassFeature.name: Madness Domain

entries: A Warlock? I may be mad, but I'm not {@b that} mad!
entries.by: {@b {@i Fane Sorell Denholm}}, {@i The 1st White Duke}.

entries: Madness. Madness is both powerful and dangerous. Those who adopt this domain need a strong mind to resist its more perverse effect. Gods of the Maddness domain are often time devious, malevolent and manipulative, draining the sanity of mortals to increase their power. Other see themselves as liberators, and promise their followers that by offering their devotion to them, they will break the shackles of reason and reality that is holding their mind down, opening their mind to a whole new world of possibility.
Clerics choosing this domain can sometimes find themselves lost in thoughts with themselves, rambling incohenrently or debating the most outlandish subjects.
At each indicated cleric level, add the listed spells to your spells prepared. They do not count towards your limit.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Cantrips
entries: When you choose this domain at 1st level, you gain the {@spell vicious mockery} cantrip. It is a cleric cantrip for you, and does not count against your maximum number of cleric cantrips.

subclassFeature.name: Inscrutable Mind
entries: Also at 1st level, your mind becomes a place where reality is a vague concept at best, giving you a very colorful imagination. You become proficient in the {@skill Deception} skill.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Madness Overtaking
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to call upon your deity to taint your magic with the seeds of insanity.

When you cast one of your domain spells, you can expand a use of Channel Divinity to select a target. If there are multiple target, choose one among all the targets affected by your spell. That target must make an additional Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. If the creature fails, it becomes afflicted with a randomly determined short term madness (see "{@book Madness Effects|dmg|8|Madness Effects}" in chapter 8 of the Dungeon Master's Guide).

subclassFeature.name: Spreading Insanity
entries: Your magic becomes so potent that it can affect the minds of multiple creatures.

Starting at 6th level, when you use your Channel Divinity to use the Madness Overtaking feature, you can affect a number of creatures within 30 feet equal to your Wisdom modifier. Roll a random short term madness for each affected creatures.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any cleric cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Creeping Mania
entries: Starting at 17th level, your insidious magic takes hold of your target's mind and assaults it until it shatters, turning your victims into gibbering messes.

At the beginning of a creature's turn that is under a charm effect from one of your spells or magical effects, it takes 3d8 psychic damage. Taking damage from this effect doesn't provoke any additional Wisdom check to try and break the effects of the charm.

subclassFeature.name: Time Domain
entries: Gods of time—including Labelas Enoreth, Savras, Istus, Chronos, the Moirai and specifically Erestem in Ilúvë—govern the passing of years and the turning of seasons. These deities oversee cause and effect, providing a background against which the course of history unfolds. They are also gods of fate and of the inevitable, responsible for the fulfillment of prophecies and the destinies of mortals. Clerics of gods of time are granted knowledge of events in the distant past and the far future, and are tasked with protecting prophecies and ensuring pivotal moments in history.
At each indicated cleric level, you add the listed spells to your spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Knight of the Old Ways
entries: {@i 1st-level Time Domain feature}
Starting at 1st level, you gain proficiency with Heavy Armor and Martial Weapons.

subclassFeature.name: Oracle of Chronology
entries: {@i 1st-level Time Domain feature}

Also starting at 1st level, your deity allows you to glimpse moments from history and of possible futures. You gain proficiency in the {@skill History} skill, and you learn the {@spell guidance} cantrip if you don't already know it.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Temporal Continuum
entries: {@i 2nd-level Time Domain feature}
Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to briefly speed up time for yourself.
You can use your Channel Divinity to take the Attack, Dash or Use an Object actions as a bonus action.
Additionally, when you cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action, you can use your Channel Divinity to change its casting time to 1 bonus action for this casting.

subclassFeature.name: Visions of the Fourth Dimension
entries: {@i 6th-level Time Domain feature}
Starting at 6th level, your ability to alter the flow of time around you becomes almost instinctual.
You gain proficiency in Dexterity saving throws, and you can no longer be surprised while you are conscious.

In addition, you may choose to target objects, as well as creatures, with your domain spells. For example, you can cast the {@spell slow} spell on a rolling boulder or the {@spell feather fall} spell on falling glass.

subclassFeature.name: Meridian Combatant
entries: {@i 8th-level Time Domain feature}
Starting at 8th level, you gain advantage on initiative rolls. In addition, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action.

subclassFeature.name: Temporal Mastery
entries: {@i 17th-level Time Domain feature}
At 17th level, you gain the {@spell time stop} and {@spell foresight} spells as domain spells. In addition, you stop aging, and you do not suffer the effects of old age.
Also at 17th level, you no longer suffer the negative effects of the {@spell haste} spell, and the {@spell slow} spell no longer affects you, unless you wish to be affected.

subclassFeature.name: Trickery Domain (Revised)
entries: The Gods of trickery—whether they are goodwilled such as {@deity Avandra|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} and {@deity Sehanine|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} or ill-meaning such as {@deity Tharizdun|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight}, {@deity Takhisis|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} and {@deity Zehir|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight}—are mischief-makers and instigators who stand as a constant challenge to the accepted order among both gods and mortals. They're patrons of thieves, scoundrels, gamblers, rebels and liberators. Their clerics are a disruptive force in the world, puncturing pride, mocking tyrants, stealing from the rich, freeing captives, and flouting hollow traditions. They prefer subterfuge, pranks, deception, and theft rather than direct confrontation.
At each indicated cleric level, you add the listed spells to your spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Blessing of the Trickster
entries: {@i 1st-level Trickery Domain feature}

Starting when you choose this domain at 1st level, you can use your action to touch yourself or one willing creature to give it advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks. This blessing lasts for 1 hour or until you use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: {@i 1st-level Trickery Domain feature}
You gain proficiency in the {@skill stealth} skill and {@item thieves' tools}.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Invoke Duplicity
entries: {@i 2nd-level Trickery Domain feature}
Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to create an illusory duplicate of yourself.

As an action, you create a perfect illusion of yourself that lasts for 1 minute. The illusion appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within 30 feet of you. As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the illusion up to 30 feet to a space you can see, but it must remain within 120 feet of you.

For the duration, you can cast spells as though you were in the illusion's space, but you must use your own senses. Additionally, whenever you are within 5 feet of your illusion, enemies have disadvantage on melee attack rolls against you, given how distracting the illusion is to the target.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Cloak of Shadows
entries: {@i 6th-level Trickery Domain feature}
Starting at 6th level, you can use your Channel Divinity to vanish.

As a reaction to taking damage, you can expend a use of your Channel Divinity to turn {@condition invisible} until the end of your next turn. You remain invisible until you attack, make a damage roll or force someone to make a saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: {@i 8th-level Trickery Domain feature}
Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any cleric cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Strike
entries: {@i 8th-level cleric {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}, which replaces the Potent Spellcasting feature}

In battle, you are blessed with divine might. When a creature takes damage from one of your spells or weapon attacks, you can also deal {@damage 1d8} radiant damage to that creature. Once you deal this damage, you can't use this feature again until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Duplicity
entries: {@i 17th-level Trickery Domain feature}

At 17th level, you can create up to four duplicates of yourself, instead of one, when you use Invoke Duplicity. As a bonus action on your turn, you can move any number of them up to 30 feet, to a maximum range of 120 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of The Mushroom

entries: Some Mushroom friends! Tasty friends.

Druids of the circle of the mushroom are mellow protectors of the fungal jungles. Their order gathers amid clouds of spores, stumbling through the deepest, most toxic clouds, sustained by visions of strange alternate realities, the very essence that ties these druids to a nature both more wondrous and strange than regular mortals can perceive.

Your link to fungus and your ability to tap into hazy visions and strange toxins grants you access to certain spells. At 2nd level, you learn the infestation cantrip.  At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of the Mushroom Spells table.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: You learn the {@spell spare the dying} cantrip and the 1st-level spells {@spell cure wounds} and {@spell inflict wounds}. You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Circle of The Mushroom Spells table. Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Fungal Tap
entries: As a bonus action, you can draw on a reservoir of fungus that courses through your entire being to empower yourself for 1 minute, or until you use this feature again. For the duration, you gain one of the following benefits of your choice:

items.name: Overgrowth
items.entry: When you choose this benefit, and as a bonus action on subsequent turns while the benefit lasts, you can expend and roll one Hit Die. You regain a number of hit points equal to the number rolled plus your spellcasting ability modifier.

items.name: Withering Strike
items.entry: When you deal damage, you can change the damage type to necrotic, and you ignore resistance to necrotic damage.

entries: You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Parasitic Fungus
entries: You gain the ability to release spores that grant you control over the body of others.

As an action, you can target one creature you can see within 15 feet of you, spraying it with a puff of tiny spores. The creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. If it fails the saving throw, it is {@condition charmed} by you for one hour or until you or your companions do anything harmful to it. While {@condition charmed}, the creature is friendly to you. Additionally, as an action, you can extend your awareness to control and see through the charmed creature's eyes and hear what it hears, gaining the benefits of any special senses that the creature has. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses. If the creature takes damage of any kind, you must succeed on a concentration check against the damage it took, or have the charm end.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Spreading Spores
entries: Beginning at 10th level the spores within you make you deadlier in battle. You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Fungal Body
entries: At 14th level, the fungal spores in your body alter you: you can't be {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, or {@condition poisoned}, and any critical hit against you counts as a normal hit instead, unless you're {@condition incapacitated}.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Protector
entries: A vanguard is a blessed fighter who protects their allies through self-sacrifice, one blessed by deities of War or Protection
Those who take up this archetype stand their ground against any adversary, willing to lay down their lives for the greater good.

subclassFeature.name: Aegis
entries: {@i 3rd-level Vanguard feature}

You are blessed with divine power that you can draw on to protect others from harm. When a creature attacks a target other than you that is within 10 feet of you, you can use your reaction to redirect the damage of that attack to yourself.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to 1 + Proficiency Bonus (PB). When you finish a short or long rest, you regain all expended uses.
The range of this feature increases by 5 feet when you reach  5th level, 7th level, and 9th level.

subclassFeature.name: Fortitude
entries: {@i 3rd-level Vanguard feature}
Starting at 3rd level, your courage is unwavering in the face of danger to protect others. While a friendly creature is in range of your Aegis:

items: You have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks to ensure their safety.
You are immune to being frightened.
You gain a +1 bonus to AC.

subclassFeature.name: Perseverance
entries: {@i 7th-level Vanguard feature}
Starting at 7th level, your resolve to fulfill your duty is unrivaled. You can use your Second Wind feature twice before you must finish a short or long rest to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Fighting Style
entries: {@i 10th-level Vanguard feature}
At 10th level, you can choose either Defense or Protection from the Fighting Style class feature.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Aegis
entries: {@i 15th-level Vanguard feature}
Starting at 15th level, your Aegis has been bolstered by your determination. You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing and slashing damage redirected to you by your Aegis.

subclassFeature.name: Last Stand
entries: {@i 18th-level Vanguard feature}
Starting at 18th level, if you are killed instantaneously, roll a death saving throw. On a success, you drop to 1 hit point instead.

subclassFeature.name: The Marauder
entries: {@i 3rd-level Marauder feature}
The archetypal Marauder focuses on brute force to overcome their enemies.
Those who model themselves on this archetype combine rigorous training with physical excellence to deal devastating blows.

subclassFeature.name: Concussive Blows
entries: {@i 3rd-level Marauder feature}
Starting at 3rd level, you strike with uncanny force. When you hit another creature with a melee weapon attack, the target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.
The saving throw DC for this feature is calculated as follows: 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Brawny
entries: {@i 7th-level Marauder feature}
Starting at 7th level, your muscles grow larger. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Athletics} skill, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses Athletics.
Aditionally, whenever you are required to make an Intimidation check, you may make the check as a Strength ({@skill Intimidation}) check, instead of Charisma.

subclassFeature.name: Stay Down
entries: {@i 10th-level Marauder feature}
Starting at 10th level, you learn to subdue your enemies. When a creature within 5 feet of you stands up, you can use your reaction to make a melee weapon attack against them.
If the target is knocked prone, their speed becomes 0 until the end of their turn.

subclassFeature.name: Tenacity
entries: {@i 15th-level Marauder feature}
Starting at 15th level, your persistence is unrivaled. You can use your Second Wind feature twice before you must finish a short or long rest to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Finishing Blow
entries: {@i 18th-level Marauder feature}
Starting at 18th level, you learn the best way to crack a skull. When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can add 10 + your Strength modifier to the attack's damage.
If a creature drops to 0 hit points in this way, it is killed instantaneously.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Way of Time
entries: The Chroniclers is among the oldest groups of Ilúvë, dedicated to recovering ancient accounts, as well as recording current events, which they call the 'Old Ways' or 'Elder Way'. Originally established as a group of inquisitive scribes and scholars, the Chroniclers have since been branded as conspirators and have gone into hiding. It is said they make their home on the Isle of Mystar, a strange magical island near the Gnomish Archipelago of The Isles.

Even though the Chronicles are thus extremely reclusive, members of the Order can usually be recognized by their distinctive clothing, from which they get the nickname 'grey cloaks' (though apparently, their garments are now of a pale yellow color). The Chroniclers are governed by a body known as the Council of Artaeum. The Council is led by a single scholar who can hold various titles, including Ritemaster and Loremaster.

It is widely know that The Red Tower, and, by proxy, The Unsorcerors, were created as a catalyst of the Chroniclers' disappearance, and had begun to develop in 2E 230, started by the right hand of the then-Loremaster, Archivist Dendur Bran.

The Chroniclers, to most unknown, also created a small off-shoot of their order, the "Hand of Eon's Minute". This order has, since the Chroniclers have gone into hiding, reinstated itself in Thalor Ancalen, near the Cloakwood Forest. The monks of this monastic order teach a modified "Elder Way", wherein they believe and teach that Ki energy is the vital way to unlocking the secrets of time.

subclassFeature.name: Mystic Timestopper
entries: {@i 3rd-level Way of Time feature}

Beginning at 3rd level when choosing this tradition, immidiately after you use your unarmed strike, you can choose to move up to 10 feet away without expending any movement, as you momentarily stop time. This movement does not provoke an attack of opportunity.
You can use this ability twice, and you regain any expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Speech of Importance
entries: {@i 6th-level Way of Time feature}
Starting at 6th level, you gain the ability to discreetly talk to others, by stopping time for a brief moment.

As an action, you can communicate with any number of creatures you can see within 30 feet of you. When you do so, time stops for everyone except for you and the creature you are talking to. You and the creature must be able to understand eachother, and the creature must be able to speak at least one language.

To speak in this way, it requires concentration, as if concentrating on a spell. Whenever you do this, you and the creature cannot move, make attack rolls, cast spells or take any other actions beside talking. If the creature you want to talk to is unwilling to talk to you or is actively fighting you, this ability fails for them.
When you reach 13th level, and you can speak to them regardless of whether you share a language.
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your wisdom modifier. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Deliberated Clairvoyance
entries: {@i 11th-level Way of Time feature}
Starting at 11th level, the insight you have gained from the Order grants you vision of the spiritual world.
You can see into the ethereal plane out of a range of 30 feet, and can cast the {@spell detect magic} and {@spell identify} spells once per long rest each.
In addition, you gain darkvision out to a range of 30 feet, or increase it by 30 if you already have darkvision.

subclassFeature.name: Channeled Dilation
entries: {@i 17th-level Way of Time feature}
Starting at 17th level, you gain the ability to step backwards or forwards in time, gaining special benefits for each.
As a bonus action on your turn, you can expend two ki points and jump backwards in time, regaining hit points equal to 1d6 + your wisdom modifier, and appearing 30 feet in any direction you can see.
Alternatively, as a bonus action on your turn, you can expend two ki points to jump forwards in time, gaining resistance to force damage until the end of your next turn, and 30 feet extra movement.

subclassFeature.name: Way of The Moon Soul
entries: Monks of the Way of The Moon Soul are strong, capable warriors, who use their style of fighting to unleash powerful attacks. Their stoic nature keeps them in a calm state of constant meditation, allowing them to be unflappable in the face of danger.

Unlike the Way of The Sun Soul, they are more defensive and fight in the front lines, focussing all their efforts to take down one enemy at a time. They will also attempt to avoid conflict if possible, but aren't afraid to get their hands dirty.

entries.subclassFeature: Fist of The New Moon|Monk||Moon Soul|WorldOfLight|3

subclassFeature.name: Fist of The New Moon
entries: {@i 3rd-level Way of The Moon Soul feature}
Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you can catch enemies off guard with a powerful opening strike.
You have advantage on initiative rolls, and you have advantage on attack rolls against creatures that haven't taken a turn in combat yet.

In addition, the first creature you hit during combat with one of your unarmed strikes takes an extra {@dice 1d10} radiant damage. Once you've used this ability, you can't do so again until you've rolled initiative, had a short rest or a long rest. This damage increases as you gain monk levels—to {@dice 2d10} at 5th level, {@dice 3d10} at 11th level, and {@dice 4d10} at 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Path of Illumination
entries: {@i 3rd-level Way of The Moon Soul feature}

Also at 3rd level when you choose this tradition, you can cast the {@spell light} cantrip at will, requiring no components. The light is a special light however; it sheds moonlight instead of normal light.
