In addition, you either gain darkvision out to a range of 30 feet (if you don't have any), or increase it by 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Channeling The Night
entries: {@i 6th-level Way of The Moon Soul feature}
Starting at 6th level, your innate connection to the power of the night sky deepens, allowing you to draw upon this connection to unleash a devastating surge of celestial energy.
You gain the ability to cast the {@spell Moonbeam}, {@spell Faerie Fire} and {@spell Guiding Bolt} spells once per short or long rest each.
Your spellcasting ability for these spells is Wisdom.

subclassFeature.name: Starforger
entries: {@i 11th-level Way of The Moon Soul feature}

At 11th level, you gain the ability to summon small celestial comets from the heavens. As an action you can magically summon small comets in a 20-foot-radius sphere at a point within 60 feet of you. Every creature hostile to you in that 20-foot-radius sphere must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take {@dice 4d12} radiant damage. Any allies (which you designate when you use this ability) within that same radius instead heal the same amount rolled. A creature doesn't need to make the save if it has total {@quickref cover|PHB|3|1} from above.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus per long rest.

In addition, you no longer need to sleep and can't be forced to sleep by any means. To gain the benefits of a long rest, you can spend all 8 hours doing light activity, such as meditating, reading or keeping watch.

subclassFeature.name: Lunar Eclipse
entries: {@i 17th-level Way of The Moon Soul feature}

At 17th level, you can call upon the might of both moons. As a bonus action, you can expend 4 ki points to enter into a lunar trance, for 1 minute. While in a lunar trance, your eye color changes to the colors of the two moons, and you gain the following benefits:

items: You can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 120 feet.
You become immune to radiant damage.
Each of your melee weapon attacks deals an additional {@dice 2d6} radiant damage.

entries: After using this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can do so again.
In addition, you no longer provoke opportunity attacks when you move out of an enemy's reach.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Wild
entries: Monks of the Way of the Wild are rare, and almost all of them have a different background and way of fighting.
Unlike most Monks, these monks have more in common with Druids or Rangers, and most Rangers might dip into this subclass for close-quarters combat.

subclassFeature.name: Tranquil as the Forest
entries: {@i 3rd-level Way of The Wild feature}

Due to your connection with nature and the forces that bind it, your Mystical touch can heal wounds. Starting at 3rd level, you have a pool of magical healing power that replenishes when you take a long rest. With that pool, you can restore a total number of hit points equal to your monk level × 10.
As an action, you can touch a creature and draw power from the pool to restore a number of hit points to that creature, up to the maximum amount remaining in the pool.

Instead of healing the creature, you can expend 5 hit points from your pool of healing to cure the target of one disease or neutralize one poison affecting it. You can cure multiple diseases and neutralize multiple poisons with a single use of Healing Hands, expending hit points separately for each one.
When you use your Flurry of Blows, you can replace one of the unarmed strikes with a use of this feature.
This feature has no effect on undead and constructs.

subclassFeature.name: Reclusive Mind
entries: {@i 3rd-level Way of The Wild feature}

Whether by will of a larger order or by your own personal training, you hone your disciplines by spending extended periods of time in the wild. Choose one bonus Proficiency from: {@skill Animal Handling}, {@skill Nature} or {@skill Survival}.

subclassFeature.name: Touch of Thorns
entries: {@i 6th-level Way of The Wild feature}
Starting 6th Level, you gain the ability to manipulate plants into deadly thorns.
You gain the ability to cast the {@spell Thorn Whip} Cantrip. In addition, you can also spend 3 ki points to cast the {@spell Spike Growth} spell.
Wisdom is your Spellcasting ability for these spells.

subclassFeature.name: Ancient Oak's Acumen
entries: {@i 11th-level Way of The Wild feature}

Starting at 11th level your attunement with nature has expanded your senses. Your meditations in the forest have taught you to recognize the flow of ki through all creatures, regardless of origin. You can direct your attacks towards an enemy's ki which are invisible to other beings and most other monks: You can use Wisdom instead of Dexterity for the Attack and Damage Rolls for your unarmed strikes, with which you then deal psychic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Spirits
entries: {@i 17th-level Way of The Wild feature}
At 17th Level, you uncover the ability to enhance your allies using the power of the Spirits of Nature.
When you are below half of your total hit points, all allies within 30ft of you gain to-hit and damage bonuses equal to your Wisdom Modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of the Open Sea
entries: The Oath of the Open Sea calls to sea-faring warriors, swashbuckling sailors, and journeying guardians who seek the thrill of an endless horizon. Driven to seek the adventure and mystery across and beneath every endless oceanic expanse, paladins who swear this oath stand against those who would deny the liberties afforded to likeminded travelers, rooting out the tyrannical and corrupt that claim any shore. Such guardians believe in the natural beauty of the sea, often making offerings and prayers to entities or deities like the Wild Mother or Storm Lord that influence safe passage, while often feeling called to hunt those monstrosities that seek to terrorize and spoil the waters with wanton violence and ill intent.

entries.subclassFeature: Tenets of the Open Sea|Paladin||Open Sea|WorldOfLight|3
Channel Divinity: Fury of the Tides|Paladin||Open Sea|WorldOfLight|3

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of the Open Sea
entries: The tenets of the Oath of the Open Sea vary by paladin, but all the tenets revolve around being on the open sea, and protecting the waters of the world. Paladins who uphold these tenets often bind themselves to protecting the seas and wayfinding, making allies along the ever-treacherous way. The core principles of the tenets are in simple sailor's terms.

entries.name: No Greater Life than a Life Lived Free
entries: One should be free to chart their own path without oppression. Those who would exert their power to dominate others shall be smote.

entries.name: Trust the Skies
entries: The guidance of a strong breeze. The rumbling warnings of a coming storm. Nature is a source of portent and council that should be heeded.

entries.name: Adapt like the Water
entries: The waters of the ocean can shift around any obstacle or become an impassable one. They can carve around and reveal the secrets of the past or swallow the truth and hide it forever. To embrace this fluidity is to be ready for any challenge.

entries.name: Explore the Uncharted
entries: The world is filled with much mystery. Through the pursuit of these enigmatic ends, one can both uncover those who hide their dark deeds in shadow to be judged, and find the path to becoming something great.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

entries.caption: Oath of Vengeance Spells
rows: {@spell create or destroy water}, {@spell expeditious retreat}

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Marine Layer
entries: {@i 3rd-level Oath of The Open Sea feature}

As an action you can channel the sea to create a thick cloud of fog that surrounds you and heavily obscures the area for 20 feet in all directions, following you as you move. You and all creatures within 5 feet of you instead treat this fog as lightly obscured. This fog lasts for 10 minutes, spreads around corners and cannot be dispersed.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Fury of the Tides
entries: {@i 3rd-level Oath of The Open Sea feature}

As a bonus action, you can channel the powerful might of the waves to bolster your attacks for 1 minute. Once per turn for the duration, when you hit a creature with weapon attack, you can choose to push the target 10 feet away from you. If the target is pushed into an obstacle or another creature, they take additional bludgeoning damage equal to your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Liberation
entries: {@i 7th-level Oath of The Open Sea feature}

Starting at 7th level, you emanate an aura while you’re not {@condition incapacitated}. You and any creature of your choice within 10 feet of you cannot be {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained}, as well as ignore penalties on movement or attacks while underwater. Creatures that are already {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained} when they enter the aura can spend 5 feet of movement to automatically escape nonmagical restraints.
When you reach 18th level in this class, the range of the aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Stormy Waters
entries: {@i 15th-level Oath of The Open Sea feature}

At 15th level, you can call crashing waters around you as a reaction whenever a creature enters or exits your melee range. The creature takes {@dice 1d12} bludgeoning damage and must succeed a Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

subclassFeature.name: Mythic Swashbuckler
entries: {@i 20th-level Oath of The Open Sea feature}

At 20th level, you learn to channel the spirits of historic sea captains to briefly become a paragon of heroic adventure. As an action, you embrace these spirits of the sea, gaining the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: Climbing costs no additional movement, and you have advantage on Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks.
If you are within 5 feet of a creature, and no other creatures are within 5 feet of you, you have advantage on your attacks against that creature.
You can take the {@action Dodge} action as a bonus action.
You have advantage on all Dexterity ability checks and Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: The Deviant
entries: The Deviant Warlock is a Warlock that specializes in the art of Trickery and Deception. They might have secret identities or other such spells to mask their identities, and are notorious for wreaking havoc wherever they may pass.

Your patron is a deity of a Trickery domain; ideally Asmodeus or other Betrayer Gods, or the vicious aspects of Sehanine. Any devil might do too, such as a Succubus, Rakshasa (These work very well) or some other Tricksy Fiend.

entries.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Deviant lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Satirical Sorcery
entries: {@i 1st-level Deviant feature}
Starting at 1st level, you learn the {@spell vicious mockery} and {@spell guidance} cantrips. They are warlock cantrips for you, and they don't count against your number of cantrips known.

subclassFeature.name: Crown of Lies
entries: {@i 1st-level Deviant feature}

Also starting at 1st level, you gain proficiency in the Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) and Charisma ({@skill Deception}) skills. If you already have proficiency in either of these skills, you add double your proficiency bonus instead. Moreover, when you make a Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check to have someone believe something you say, treat a roll of 7 or lower on the d20 as an 8.

subclassFeature.name: Duplicitous Double Speak
entries: {@i 6th-level Deviant feature}

Starting at 6th level, your patron has taught you the ways of using subterfuge in both speech and action. You can use your reaction to cast the {@spell mirror image} spell once per short or long rest without expending a spell slot.

In addition, you learn the {@spell friends} cantrip, which doesn't count against your number of cantrips you know, and you can choose whether the creature realizes you used magic to influence its mood or not when you cast it.

subclassFeature.name: Illusory Facsimile
entries: {@i 10th-level Deviant feature}

Starting at 10th level, you can create an illusionary duplicate of yourself at will. Unlike other illusionary duplicates, it seems completely real, including sounds, smells, and temperature appropriate to yourself.
While not in combat, the illusionary duplicate can perform simple tasks such as standing watch, relaying a message, performing an act, and aiding another creature verbally.
The illusionary duplicate will remain until you use this feature again, dismiss it, or if you are more than 120 feet away from it.

subclassFeature.name: Malefic Illusions
entries: {@i 14th-level Deviant feature}
Starting at 14th level, your illusionary duplicates can deal damage or otherwise directly harm anyone.
When an illusionary duplicate mimics a weapon attack it deals {@dice 1d10} + your Charisma modifier in psychic damage.

subclassFeature.name: The Hexblade
entries: You have made a pact with a mysterious entity. This entity, whatever it may be, has granted you—or sometimes even is—a weapon carved from the boon that a Hexblade calls their pact. While unknown to many, Hexblades come in many a form. Some gain their power from the stuff of shadow, while others have made a pact with the blade itself.

The mighty sword {@i Dawnbreaker} is the most notable Hexblade weapon, which has been spread across the world over the ages, carried by a Warlock said to have made a pact with the goddess {@deity Auroril|Ilúvë|WorldOfLight} herself. Sages believe that almost every being with sufficient power could create a pact blade and give it to their followers, yet this brings into question what (or perhaps whom) binds these pacts in the first place.

entries.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Hexblade lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Hexblade's Curse
entries: {@i 1st-level Hexblade feature}

Starting at 1st level, you gain the ability to place a baleful curse on someone. As a bonus action, choose one creature you can see within 30 feet of you. The target is cursed for 1 minute. The curse ends early if the target dies, you die, or you are {@condition incapacitated}. Until the curse ends, you gain the following benefits:

items: You gain a bonus to damage rolls against the cursed target. The bonus equals your proficiency bonus.
Any attack roll you make against the cursed target is a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20 on the {@dice d20}.
If the cursed target dies, you regain hit points equal to your warlock level + your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1 hit point).

entries: You can't use this feature again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Hex Warrior
entries: {@i 1st-level Hexblade feature}
At 1st level, you acquire the training necessary to effectively arm yourself for battle. You gain proficiency with medium armor, shields, and martial weapons.

The influence of your patron also allows you to mystically channel your will through a particular weapon. Whenever you finish a long rest, you can touch one weapon that you are proficient with and that lacks the two-handed property. When you attack with that weapon, you can use your Charisma modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls. This benefit lasts until you finish a long rest. If you later gain the Pact of the Blade feature, this benefit extends to every pact weapon you conjure with that feature, no matter the weapon's type.

subclassFeature.name: Spellsword
entries: {@i 6th-level Hexblade feature}
Beginning at 6th level, when you use your action to cast a cantrip, you can make one weapon attack as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Armor of Hexes
entries: {@i 10th-level Hexblade feature}

At 10th level, your hex grows more powerful. If the target cursed by your Hexblade's Curse hits you with an attack roll, you can use your reaction to roll a {@dice d6}. On a 4 or higher, the attack instead misses you, regardless of its roll.

subclassFeature.name: Master of Hexes
entries: {@i 14th-level Hexblade feature}

Starting at 14th level, you can spread your Hexblade's Curse from a slain creature to another creature. When the creature cursed by your Hexblade's Curse dies, you can apply the curse to a different creature you can see within 30 feet of you, provided you aren't {@condition incapacitated}. When you apply the curse in this way, you don't regain hit points from the death of the previously cursed creature.

subclassFeature.name: Chronurgy Magic
entries: Focusing on the manipulation of time, those who follow the Chronurgy tradition learn to alter the pace of reality to their liking. Using the ramping of anticipatory divination magic, these mages can bend the flow of time as adroitly as a skilled musician plays an instrument, lending themselves and their allies an advantage in the blink of an eye.

subclassFeature.name: Relativity Savant
entries: {@i 2nd-level Chronurgy Magic feature}
Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the time you must spend to copy any spell into your spellbook is halved.

subclassFeature.name: Chronal Shift
entries: {@i 2nd-level Chronurgy Magic feature}

You can magically exert limited control over the flow of time around a creature. As a reaction, after you or a creature you can see within 30 feet of you makes an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw, you can force the creature to reroll. You make this decision after you see whether the roll succeeds or fails. The target must use the result of the second roll.
You can use this ability twice, and you regain any expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Temporal Awareness
entries: {@i 2nd-level Chronurgy Magic feature}
You can add your Intelligence modifier to your initiative rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Momentary Stasis
entries: {@i 6th-level Chronurgy Magic feature}

As an action, you can magically force a Large or smaller creature you can see within 60 feet of you to make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. Unless the saving throw is a success, the creature is encased in a field of magical energy until the end of your next turn or until the creature takes any damage. While encased in this way, the creature is {@condition incapacitated} and has a speed of 0.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Abeyance
entries: {@i 10th-level Chronurgy Magic feature}

When you cast a spell using a spell slot of 4th level or lower, you can condense the spell's magic into a mote. The spell is frozen in time at the moment of casting and held within a gray bead for 1 hour. This bead is a Tiny object with AC 15 and 1 hit point, and it is immune to poison and psychic damage. When the duration ends, or if the bead is destroyed, it vanishes in a flash of light, and the spell is lost.

A creature holding the bead can use its action to release the spell within, whereupon the bead disappears. The spell uses your spell attack bonus and save DC, and the spell treats the creature who released it as the caster for all other purposes.
Once you create a bead with this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Transcendent Juncture
entries: {@i 14th-level Chronurgy Magic feature}

Starting at 14th level, glimpses of the future begin to press in on your awareness, and with it, the secrets to manipulate them. When you finish a long rest, roll three {@dice d20}s and record the numbers rolled. You can replace any attack roll, saving throw, or ability check made by you or a creature that you can see with one of these foretelling rolls. You can choose to do so before or after the roll, and you can replace a roll in this way only once per turn.

language.name: Arconic
entries: Arconic, a language spoken by the ancient and long-forgotten mages of Arcanix, is a dead tongue. Very few creatures in the world today would recognize it, much less speak it. Arconic used the Draconic alphabet in its written form, while the spoken language had many similarities with Sylvan, due to the Arcanixian mages being almost wholly comprised of Eladrin and High-Elves. A character who speaks Sylvan can understand what a creature speaking Arconic is saying, and vice versa. A character who has the {@background Cloistered Scholar|PHB} or {@background Sage|PHB} background, or a {@class warlock} who knows the {@optfeature Eyes of the Rune Keeper} invocation, can translate written Arconic without an ability check.

_.special: small {@item pouch|phb|pouches} with a random assortment of common garden seeds

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: One set of {@item Gardener's Tools|WorldOfLight}, 3 small {@item pouch|phb|pouches} with a random assortment of common garden seeds, a {@item shovel|phb}, a book about herbology, a set of {@item common clothes|phb} and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 10 gp

entries.name: Feature: Green Thumb
entries: Your weather beaten skin and dirt stained, callused hands mark you as someone who understands what it is to labour in the soil in all weathers. You can talk confidently with the common folk of the world about plants, the seasons and soil. Wherever things are cultivated and grown be it a farm, vineyard or herbgarden your knowledge and appearance ensure that you are greeted without suspicion and offered basic aid if needed.

_.special: a trinket scavenged from a dungeon or other underdark settlement

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: Undercommon and one language of your choice.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A set of {@item navigator's tools|phb}, a set of {@item traveler’s clothes|phb}, a {@item trinket|phb} scavenged from a dungeon or other Underdark settlement (or you may roll for a random {@item trinket|phb} on the Trinkets table in Chapter 5), and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 15gp

entries.name: Feature: Deep Delver
entries: You have a knack for making your way in the deep places of the world. You can recall the twists and turns of passageways and tunnels such that you can always retrace your steps underground. You're also well acquainted with foraging and survival in the Underdark, and can determine when sources of food and water are safe to consume. You can always find sufficient food and water for yourself and up to five other people in the Underdark, as long as sustenance is available in the area.

entries.name: Optional Feature: Underdark Experience
entries: You are no casual visitor to the Underdark, but instead have spent considerable time there learning its ways. You are familiar with the various races, civilizations, and settlements of the Underdark, as well as its major routes for travel. If you fail an Intelligence check to recall some piece of Underdark lore, you know a source you can consult for the answer unless the DM rules that the lore is unknown.

boon.name: Boon of the Frost
entries: You have immunity to cold damage. You can also cast {@spell frost fingers|TCE} (save DC 15) at will, without using a spell slot or any components.

reward.name: Erestem's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Erestem trait}
As a devotee of Erestem, you have proven yourself a devotee of reality and order. You can now cast {@spell fortune's favor|WorldOfLight} once per short rest without using any material components.

reward.name: Erestem's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Erestem trait}

You've thrown yourself into books and you've come back with the knowledge to bend reality without breaking order. You can now cast {@spell gravity sinkhole|EGW} once per long rest. Your intelligence is your spellcasting ability when using this feature.

reward.name: Erestem's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Erestem trait}

You've learned more about the weave of time and now can better manipulate reality, without breaking the time-space continuum. You can now use your Erestem's Devotee feature a number of times equal to your intelligence modifier (minimum of once) per short rest. Also, when you're under the effects of advantage, it can not be canceled out by any disadvantage.

reward.name: Champion of Time
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Erestem trait}
You've scoured for everything you can learn about the universe. You feel your mind expand. Increase either your wisdom or your intelligence ability score by 2, and its maximum by 2.

optionalfeature.name: Misty Nightmare
entries: You can cast the {@spell Major Image} at will, without expending a spell slot or material components.

optionalfeature.name: Devils tongue
entries: When you cast Friends, you can choose whether the creature realizes you used magic to influence its mood or not.

optionalfeature.name: Lightweight Combatant
entries: You can use two-weapon fighting even when the one-handed melee weapons you are wielding aren't light.

condition.name: Dying
entries: Whenever you are reduced to 0 hit points, you fall {@condition prone} and gain this condition. At the start of your turn, you have to make a Death Saving Throw (this functions like normal). On your turn, you can only use your action, bonus action or move action. Once you use one of these actions, your turn ends.

If you use your action on your turn, you take a cumulative -3 penalty to all your d20 rolls. If you use your bonus action on your turn, you take a cumulative -1 penalty to all your d20 rolls. If you use your reaction while you are {@condition dying}, you take a cumulative -1 penalty to all your d20 rolls. While you have this condition, you cannot use any of your actions to stand up from being {@condition prone}.

If you take {@variantrule Massive Damage} (or, in the case your DM doesn't use {@variantrule Massive Damage}, if you take half or more of your hit points in damage that results in reducing you to zero), you do not gain this condition and instead become {@condition unconscious} like normal.
